item.title: Transcending Fear (FREE Pre-Release Screening)
item.description:
Born in a cave with only stars to tell time, Gao Zhisheng overcomes incredible odds to become one of China’s top attorneys. The people call him “the Conscience of China.” But then, in the eyes of the Communist Party, his pursuit of justice goes too far.
After speaking out against taboo human rights abuses, Gao is abducted, tortured. Secret police hold his wife and children hostage. In a heart-wrenching dilemma, Gao is forced to choose between his lifelong quest for justice and his love for his family. Which path will he take? And what price will he have to pay?
A story of cruelty, courage and compassion, this film is a must-see for anyone wishing to understand the tensions bubbling below the surface of today’s China—or to meet one of the most noble freedom fighters of our time.
Film duration: 72 min Q & A: 15 min
Tea and Coffee supplied

item.title: Traverse
item.description:
Using traditional media in unconventional ways, Schawel's works are driven by a love of materials where ideas, technique and media come together.
‘Through scraping, sanding, painting, perforating, drawing, cutting, drilling and tearing, Schawel crafts her artwork in a manually intensive process that belies the graceful abstracted visions that result. Working with a pared-back palette of neutral tones that are accented by bold reds and graphic yellows, Schawel’s works appear both primordial and feather-light. The artist strikes a balance between control and chaos as she manipulates her medium and the ever-present element of surprise to create shapes and forms of a largely variegated nature. ’ Excerpt from an essay by Marguerite Brown, 2014.
Born in Illinois, USA, Melinda Schawel received a BA in Fine Art and Communication from the University of California Santa Barbara in 1993 and a Postgraduate Degree in Printmaking from RMIT, Melbourne, in 1996. She has exhibited regularly since 1995 and been selected for a number of prestigious commissions including the Westin Hotel and the Park Hyatt.
The opening for the exhibition will be held on Saturday 30 August, 1–3pm. Note that the gallery will close at 3pm on Saturday 13 September.

item.title: The Art of Botanical Illustration Exhibition
item.description:
The Friends of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne will present their twelfth biennial The Art of Botanical Illustration exhibition from 25 October to 9 November 2014 at Domain House, Dallas Brooks Drive, Melbourne 3004. The exhibition's growing international profile, amongst the worldwide resurgence in botanical illustration, has become a focus for both artists and collectors. Over 150 selected works depicting native and ornamental plants in a variety of media (mainly watercolour, pencil and ink) will be displayed and for sale. The scientific accuracy of the work submitted for selection is a critical part of the high standard expected for inclusion in the exhibition. To ensure this standard is met each artwork is carefully scrutinised and selected by an expert panel, which includes a botanist at the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne. A highlight of the exhibition is the awarding of the Celia Rosser Medal to an artist or artists whose work is judged to be of the highest possible standard. The medal, named in honour of Celia Rosser, recognises her contribution to the genre of botanical illustration, having spent 25 years recording the entire genus of Banksia for Monash University. Many beautiful works have been and will be purchased from this renowned exhhibition for inclusion in the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne's "State Botanical Collection", which is held in the National Herbarium in Melbourne. The Art of Botanical Illustration 2014 Exhibition 25 October - 9 November Domain House Gallery, Dallas Brooks Drive, Melbourne (off Birdwood Avenue, opposite the National Herbarium) Open: Weekdays 10 am to 4 pm Weekends 10 am - 6 pm Sunday 9 November: 10 am - 4 pm
On Sunday,9 November the exhibition will close at 4:00 pm.

item.title: Seymour Biography Lecture with Professor Ray Monk
item.description:
British biographer and philosopher Prof Ray Monk delivers the 2014 Seymour Biography Lecture - 'How can I be a Logician Before I'm a Human Being? The Role of Biography in the Understanding of Intellectuals'.
Drawing from his biographies 'Ludwig Wittgenstein: The Duty of Genius' (1990); 'Bertrand Russell 1921-70: The Ghost of Madness' (2000) and 'Inside The Centre: The Life of J. Robert Oppenheimer' (2013), Ray Monk will discuss the legitimate role and limitations of biography in understanding philosophers and scientists.
Ray Monk is a British biographer and is a Professor of Philosophy at the University of Southampton, where he has taught since 1992. The event is hosted by Peter Rose, Editor, Australian Book Review. The Seymour Biography Lecture commenced in 2005. The lecture has been generously endowed by Dr John Seymour and Mrs Heather Seymour, AO and since 2010 has been presented by the National Library of Australia.
Presented in Melbourne in partnership with the Australian Book Review with support from the National Library of Australia, Future Leaders and Knowledge Melbourne - a City of Melbourne initiative.
This is a Melbourne Conversations event, presented by the City of Melbourne.
Doors open 5.30pm.

item.title: School Holiday Entertainment at Harbour Town
item.description:
Enjoy free school holiday entertainment this September at Harbour Town Docklands.
During the first week of the holidays you can see Nickelodeon's Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Live Show, with two show times a day plus the chance to meet your favourite character at 12:30pm each day.
During the second week, come and pat the animals at Farmer Darryl's Animal Farm.
Ninja Turtles Live Show, 22-26 Sep, two shows daily at 11am and 1:30pm. Farmer Darryl's Animal Farm, 29 Sep-3 Oct, daily at 10:30am and 2:30pm.

item.title: QV Hideaway
item.description:
Fashion will flourish this spring at QV Melbourne with the creation of a luxe forest hideaway. Unlike anything seen in QV Square before, this enchanting woodland sanctuary will be an official venue for the Melbourne Spring Fashion Week, and will continue to grow well into the month of September.
The bespoke hub will transport visitors into a woodland forest, complete with lofty trees created from sustainable wood, vibrant tulips strewn throughout, and an enchanted tree at the heart of the hub. The venue will be nestled in the heart of QV Square, complete with a birch-covered café serving freshly roasted coffee daily.
A specially crafted giant bird nest will nestle beneath the dappled light of the canopy for visitors to rest in, whilst an expansive alfresco balcony will adorn the exterior - the perfect position to soak in the spring sunshine.
The QV Hideaway will come to life on the opening night of MSFW on Friday 29th August, where the entire shopping precinct will be open late with exclusive deals for shoppers.
The official fashion events will continue into Fashion Week, with a curated salon show on Friday 5th September highlighting the current spring trends from QV's fashion retailers including Incu, Vanishing Elephant, Obus and M Dreams.
The QV Hideaway will be the best place to seek the latest trends for the Spring Carnival with free hair and makeup styling consultations, an express eyebrow shaping bar by QV's beauty retailers and free beauty makeovers. The site will also host mini landscape and string garden workshops by Flower Temple, and cocktail master classes led by award-winning bartender Clint Weir.

item.title: Napkin Pitch Night with Adam Bandt
item.description:
On Thursday 18th September, we'll be hosting Adam Bandt (Federal Greens MP for Melbourne) and a panel of innovators in the social entrepreneurship space for a "Napkin Pitch Night"!
We will have 3 presentations on the night, speaking about:
* Local Melbourne issues * How to get into an entrepreneurial mindset * How to give a great pitch
After these presentations, attendees will have 15 minutes to come up with a "napkin pitch".
What is a napkin pitch night, you ask?
* Bring a friend or two along to the event if you want to participate. Teams can be from 2 - 5.
* On the night, we'll have short speeches with one central theme
* You'll be given a problem, and you'll have 15 minutes to come up with a one to two minute pitch for a business idea that will solve the problem.
This is a basic, informal pitch, not a lengthy business plan. Keep it short and sweet, tell us the core idea, how it will work and how it'll solve the problem at hand! Our panel will judge the pitches and award General Assembly prizes to the winners. Then, we'll have networking and drinks afterward.

item.title: Kwality Chai
item.description:
Kwality Chai installs a unique golden chai cart at Melbourne's iconic Flinders street station. The dynamic public performance presents an animated 'chai-wallah' (specialist Indian tea maker) who theatrically 'pulls' spicy tea for commuters and passers-by. From here, the alternate reality unfolds as the audience interact with a team of talented performers who play waiters who speak in an invented Indian-Australian language, an immersive soundscape, a specially published newspaper, The Kwality Times, and a 'New World' radio station playing news, stories and beats.
This provocative new work presents an uncanny intervention into the every-day, drawing in an unsuspecting public as audience to experience Australia's cross cultural identity, with the offer of tantalising Indian Chai.
Australian-Indian artist and director Sapna Chandu works with site-specific installations and has a special interest in cross-cultural narratives.
Opening night 18 September, 4pm to 8pm.

item.title: Grand Final Day at Melbourne Public
item.description:
Melbourne Public Bar & Restaurant located on the Yarra’s edge set in and around the lovingly restored heritage cargo sheds that is Melbourne’s newest dining and drinking secret, South Wharf. With interior inspired by 1920’s industrial flair of polished brass, exposed beams and heritage features, Melbourne Public celebrates the best of Melbourne’s past and present, in true Australian pub style.
Positioned only a leisurely stroll to the CBD, Docklands, Southbank, the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition centre and Etihad stadium with live music and entertainment every Friday, Saturday and Sunday and screening all your favourite sporting games live across our large screens.
AFL Grand Final Day is a big deal in Melbourne and Melbourne Public puts on a great show with 5 large screens; seriously good pub food all day; DJ’s and LIVE Music; we’re open from midday to 1am.

item.title: Fluid Festival at Blackburn Hotel
item.description:
Fluid Festival returns to Melbourne to celebrate a selection of the finest beers, wines, bourbons and ciders at the Blackburn Hotel on 21st September 2014.
Throughout the Festival, a wide variety of flavours and styles will be on offer at stalls set up outside Blackburn Hotel, with over 100 products available to sample from more than 20 local and international producers and suppliers.
In addition to tastings, you will have the opportunity to meet some of the best in the business at the ‘Meet The Brewer’ master classes featuring some of the world’s leading brewers, cider makers, distillers and wine makers.
Providing an insight into the industry and sharing their tips in short intimate sessions will be Endeavour Vintage Beer founder, Ben Kooyman, Matso’s Brewing Co ambassador Julie Mackenzie and American premium bourbon Wild Turkey ambassador, Jamie Chesher.
Crowd favourites at the Fluid Festival will be the World Beer Cup award-winning Endeavour Growler’s Bright Ale, winner of “Best Cider” at the Good Food & Wine Show 2013, Endless Cider and Matso’s Broome Brewery’s unique Mango Beer and Lychee Beer.
In addition, Fluid Festival will feature Kwencher Beer, Feral Brewing Company, Batlow Cider Co., Cavalier Brewing, Blue Moon Brewing Company, Matilda Bay Brewing Company, Wild Turkey, Sail & Anchor, Too Many Chiefs Cider, Pressman’s Cider, Knob Creek, Coldstream Brewery – and more to be announced.
You can also enjoy a delicious selection of paired food from Blackburn Hotel’s bistro, live music from Melbourne’s award-winning blues band Geoff Achison and The Soul Diggers, The Detonators and Blues Mountain as well as children’s entertainment including a jumping castle, face painting and an animal farm.

item.title: Flinders Lane Gallery 25th Anniversary Exhibition
item.description:
Since opening its doors in 1989, the gallery has actively supported Australian artists. This exhibition celebrates their love of Melbourne.
Twenty-five years and over 500 curated exhibitions later, Flinders Lane Gallery is determined to celebrate this remarkable milestone with an exhibition that pays respect to Melbourne – an incredible city that continues to actively support and nurture Australian artists.
The gallery's represented artists have created an artwork specifically for the exhibition based around the curatorial premise of representing Melbourne, and what our city means to each individual artist. The responses are varied and rich. There is a nod to Melbourne's rag trade with photographic artist Meg Cowell's striking floating dress, Agneta Ekholm makes a cheeky reference to Melbourne's love of all things black and Naomi White presents a fresh Autumn morning walk through the much loved Carlton Gardens.
Artists featured in the 25th Anniversary Exhibition include: Margaret Ackland Sarah Amos Susan Baird Richard Blackwell Terri Brooks Meg Cowell Jo Davenport Julie Davidson Jon Eiseman and many more.
Please note, that on the last Saturday of the exhibition the gallery will be closing at 3pm.

item.title: Evening of Korean Culture - Hanbok Fashion, Music and Dance
item.description:
Hamer Hall, Melbourne- In celebration of the Korean President Park Geun-hye’s visit to Australia for the forthcoming G20 summit in Brisbane and the opening of the Consulate-General of the Republic of Korea in Melbourne, the Consulate-General of the Republic of Korea in Melbourne is hosting a Korean cultural concert at the Arts Centre Melbourne (Hamer Hall- 26-28 Southgate Ave, Southbank) on Tuesday 23 September 2014 from 7:00pm to 9:15pm. The approximately two-hour concert will begin with a beautiful Hanbok fashion show. This will be followed by a traditional Korean performance, a modern dance by Jinjo Crew (b-boying) and a traditional and contemporary fusion music performance by Korean Folklore Music group Coreyah. Doors open at 6:30pm and it is free admission. For ticketing enquires, email us at rsvp@mofa.go.kr
Doors open at 6:30pm

item.title: Cooking Masterclass with a Twist
item.description:
Are you aged 18 to 25 years and keen to learn how to improve your cooking? Join a free and fun cooking workshop with Chef Rajiv from Old Pepper restaurant.
This masterclass starts with a trip to Queen Victoria Market and will then be followed by a hands-on cooking and wellbeing session with Chef Rajiv.
There will be prizes and more.

item.title: Children's Week Workshops
item.description:
During Children's Week, discover what is important about where you live in these free creative arts workshops for children aged five to eight, and nine to 12. Talented writers and illustrators Trace Balla and Kylie Dunstan will be running these tailored classes.
Children's Week is an annual event held during the fourth week in October. Celebrating the right of children to enjoy childhood, it is also a time for youngsters to discover and demonstrate their talents, skills and abilities.
These Children’s Week events are presented in partnership with the Victorian Department of Education and Early Childhood Development.

item.title: Brown & Bone
item.description:
Exploring the physicality of paint and surface textures, Dr Terri Brooks formally investigates natural mark making. With a leanness of technique and an innate feeling for surface textures, Brooks utilises her materials to produce rich and complex works that speak of creating art out of something humble and ordinary.
The works within this new body of paintings by Terri Brooks are not quite black and white. The familiar stripes, spots and ridges which draw their origin from urban architectural details are somehow made more personal, more inner as Brooks experiments with her tonality and her painting process, sometimes wet into wet, sometimes dry. The borders of the canvas too are no longer confirmed. In some works, papier-mâché spills over the edges while paper attachments frame others.
Brooks has been selected as a finalist in the Fleurieu Art Prize, the Kedumba Drawing Award, the Tattersall’s Landscape Art Prize and the Alice Prize, among others.
The opening for this event will be held on Saturday 30 August from 1p to 3pm. Note that on Saturday 13 September the gallery will close at 3pm.

item.title: Alphabet Soup
item.description:
In the series scheduled for Mailbox, Simon Mee employs his recognisable palette of blues, greys and whites in a series of drawings which form Alphabet Soup, curated by Jane O’Neill.
Simon Mee is a mid-career artist based in Toowoomba, Queensland. He has exhibited regularly throughout Australia since 1995 and is currently employed as a lecturer in drawing at the University of Southern Queensland. Mee draws fluently on a number of styles in his drawings and paintings, and is informed by a wide-ranging knowledge of art history. The artist is characteristically drawn to the absurdist elements of everyday scenarios.
Here's what Simon says about his exhibition - 'I have always had a natural talent for the visual spoonerism - being unfashionably late to the conceptual party, the wrong end of the stick or the sore end of the pineapple. It seems only appropriate that throughout my preparations for the series at Mailbox I end up with an alphabet soup. This came about as I was looking at vignettes, postcards, Punch and Judy and 19th century street imagery around boxes and narrow spaces - a time when people were literally 'boxed'. Via a circuitous route this series owes part of its narrative dialogue to pastiche, a narrative that is both individual and the sum of its parts – an alphabet as designed by a Victorian absinthe drinker'.
Opening night, Thur 4 Sept 6pm to 8pm.

item.title: All That Glitters – Inspiration from Italy and Beyond
item.description: An exhibition of recent charcoal paintings by Brian Reberger. In his latest collection, Reberger has incorporated gold or silver leaf in each image, providing extra depth and another dimension to the light in the works. Homage is paid to the Italian masters, Bernini and Cellini and the ancient use of gold leaf in religious paintings, alter pieces and church decoration, but with a modern perspective.

item.title: 2014 Hidden Faces of the Archibald Exhibition
item.description:
Victorian artistic talent is revealed at its best in this year's Hidden Faces of the Archibald portrait exhibition, with an extraordinary variety of subjects presented in a diversity of styles and techniques.
Also known in art circles as the Victorian Salon des Refuses, Hidden Faces unveils 43 paintings of such well-known subjects as sports icon Paul Salmon; performer 'Ugly' Dave Gray; artists Godwin Bradbeer, Laurie Collins and Joseph Zhubvic; writers Elliot Pearlman, Jenny Darling and Giles Parkinson; directors Fred Schepisi and Richard Bence; politicians Ted Baillieu and Joan KIrner AM; and judiciaries the Honourable Tony Pagone, Geoffrey Robertson QC and Dr. Gregory Lyon QC.
Now it its thirteenth year, the exhibition continues to bring to the spotlight the amazing portraiture talent in Victoria. Artists include Jacquie Blight, Jim van Geet, Ursula Theinert, Andrew Sibley, Polly Ifould, Annie On Lee, Dawn Stubbs, Ross Cockle, David Bryant,Victor Majzner, Steve May, Anna Minardo, Caroline Thew and Vicki Sullivan.
The exhibition follows in the long tradition of the French Impressionists of the 1860s, who held a breakaway exhibition from the reactionary French Academy. The People's Choice Award is a visitor's favourite with prizes provided by the Hilton Melbourne South Wharf.

item.title: The Ways of Winged Ones and Women
item.description:
The Ways of Winged Ones and Women weaves folktale, myth and history. Created with the environment of the Docklands especially in mind, this tale contemplates the nomadic and migratory movements of women and birds. Through the air and across oceans, these precarious journeys create webs of deep connection.
For millennia, the migratory birds of our wetlands have journeyed annually to the arctic tundra and back again following the East Asian–Australasian Flyway. Without instinct or wings but with beating hearts, thousands of women crossed oceans, disembarking in the burgeoning colony to begin new lives, for better or for worse.
Insatiably curious and delightfully mischievous, Jackie Kerin and Teena Hartnett's passion for history and folk tales is contagious.
Doors open 5.30pm; performance starts 6pm sharp.

item.title: Ballarat Regional Arts Trail
item.description:
Twelve of Ballart and district's artists have come together to create the fourth annual "Arts Trail" across Ballarat and district at various venues.
These artists are passionate about their art and will open their studios and workshops to the public allowing people to view first hand their working environment and their art work.
A variety of working styles and artist's media will be on display ranging from the stone carver and a bodger, to the textile artists using eco printing, Shibori and stitch to express themselves. Painters working in a variety of mediums, including watercolour, pastels, oils and mixed media. To ceramic artists whose works are both beautiful and functional. This year introduces several new artists who are very involved in the reclaiming and recycling of found objects into new pieces of art work. The group aims to have something that would appeal to everyone.
All wish to provide greater access to the arts for a broader sector of the art loving public whilst hoping to attract those who are not regular gallery goers but have an interest in what's out there. One of their aims is to encourage people to investigate other forms of art rather than just the traditional methods.
All the artists work from their home studios which range from dedicated work areas, unique studios to garages which have been converted into a functional art making space. They are happy to talk about their artistic inspiration and show their work to the visitor. Work will also be for sale at studio prices at all venues.
Arts Trail maps are available from the Ballarat Tourist Information Centre, the Art Gallery of Ballarat and the Creswick Tourist Information Centre.
Entry is free
Watch for the Blue Flags. For further information please call or email operator or visit their website.

item.title: Polish Festival
item.description:
Spend a day experiencing the colours, sounds and aromas of Poland at the Polish Festival 2014 at Fed Square.
Victoria has the largest concentration of Polish born people and their descendants in Australia. Join them for a huge program of celebrations and activities that showcases the very best of their unique culture right here in the heart of Melbourne.
Enjoy live music performances, traditional dances, special acts and entertainment running all day on the main stage. Take a stroll down River Terrace and explore stalls selling a variety of Polish crafts, artworks, books, jewellery and other trinkets. You can also taste some of the finest polish treats with a delectable array of authentic foods on offer.
Kids can get creative with arts and crafts activities running all day at the Kid's Stop, while adults head to the beer garden to relax and sample from the world-class ale on offer.

item.title: South Indian Food Festival
item.description:
Discover the culinary secrets of South India with the exciting new South Indian Food Festival at Fed Square.
Presented by the Telugu Association of Australia, this all-day event aims to introduce Melburnians to many of the untouched traditional foods of South India.
You can experience the rich and exotic flavours with an array of stalls along River Terrace.

item.title: lphabet Soup: Simon Mee
item.description:
Simon Mee is a mid-career artist based in Toowoomba, Queensland. He has exhibited regularly throughout Australia since 1995 and is currently employed as a lecturer in drawing at the University of Southern Queensland. Mee draws fluently on a number of styles in his drawings and paintings, and is informed by a wide-ranging knowledge of art history.
The artist is characteristically drawn to the absurdist elements of everyday scenarios. In the series scheduled for Mailbox, Mee employs his recognisable palette of blues, greys and whites in a series of drawings which form Alphabet Soup.

item.title: Wedding Open Day
item.description:
The Yarra Valley Lodge is hosting an exclusive Wedding Open Day with the opportunity to enjoy a tour of their superb reception and ceremony venues, accommodation and all other hotel facilities followed by casual high tea and featuring their local suppliers.
Join them for the next Wedding Open Day on Sunday 14th September, 10am to 3pm. To register to attend the Wedding Open Day please contact them by phone or email.

item.title: Climate Watch Walk
item.description:
Be a Climate Watcher! Join a guide at the Royal Botanic Gardens and a ClimateWatch Scientist on this free guided walk.
During the walk, record features of specific plants and animals in the Gardens. These observations will become part of a database that helps scientists see what impact climate change is having on particular species, and therefore inform Australia's response to a changing climate.

item.title: Spring discovery tour
item.description: Discover the history, cultural significance and stunning beauty of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne. Take a walk among the fresh green leaves of spring on this free guided tour of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne with one of their knowledgeable guides. You can also enjoy a peaceful punt on the Ornamental Lake or relax at one of the cafes, The Terrace or Jardin Tan.

item.title: Opening of Two Colour Harmony. An exhibition by the Hamilton Quilters
item.description:
There has been a renewed interest in craft and needlework in recent years as traditional arts and crafts enjoy a revival with a younger generation.
Quilts in particular are familiar objects, yet every stitch has the power to carry a range of stories and histories. These works can often hold immense family value, lovingly handed down through the generations.
The Hamilton Quilters have been delighting Western Victoria with their dedication, skill and creativity with the popular medium of quilting for over 30 years. The upcoming exhibition at Hamilton Art Gallery will mark the group's 16th biennial exhibition in the gallery with a variety of techniques and ideas on display themed around 'Two Colour Harmony'.
Each quilter uses their own interpretation of the theme, with varied responses. The time to produce each of the quilts varies considerably with their size and detail; some of the larger quilts contain over 4000 pieces of material and may take the quilter years to complete.
Director of the Gallery Daniel McOwan commented, 'The Hamilton Quilters have pioneered quilt-making in Western Victoria. The variety of techniques and ideas displayed in their work demonstrate the skill, creativity and talent of their membership.'
Hamilton Quilters was founded around 30 years ago, and have been holding biennial exhibitions at the Gallery ever since. The exhibition 'Two Colour Harmony' will open at 2:00pm Sunday the 7th September and will be on display at the Gallery until 2nd November 2014. Entry to both the opening and exhibition are free with both quilting enthusiasts and the general public invited to attend.

item.title: Yarra Valley Bridal Expo
item.description:
The ultimate bridal experience set against the majestic beauty of the Victorian wine country is back, with the Yarra Valley Bridal Expo on 12th October.
More than 100 local exhibitors will showcase their best products and services to an expected 1000-bride crowd. There will also be a 50-car display - the biggest the wine region has ever seen.
From couture bridal gowns, florists, to photographers and cake makers, the Yarra Valley Racecourse will be transformed into mini wedding carnival, complete with delicious gourmet food and beverage samples for patrons. What's more, there will be something special for the boys with free 10-minute Lamborghini rides every hour.
According to founder and Managing Director of Riverstone Estate, Mary-Anne Lowe, this bridal expo is like no other in Victoria, if not Australia, with the choice of venue accentuating the grandeur of the Yarra Valley. All the exhibitors are passionate about the Yarra Valley and are keen to celebrate the richness and diversity of what this region has to offer. Mary-Anne Lowe also believes that by hosting the Yarra Valley Bridal Expo, brides-to-be can experience the best of bridal products and services in the one spot. Victorian brides, demand uniqueness and quality. The Yarra Valley is synonymous with luxury, choice and premium products and services. Brides won't be disappointed and will walk away from the expo very satisfied with the myriad of choices for their wedding.

item.title: Father's Day at Rochford Wines
item.description:
This Father's Day at Isabella's at Rochford Wines in the Yarra Valley - a locally brewed, ice cold beer will be delivered free to every person who orders from the special, one day only, Father's Day menu.
Choose between the Wagyu, Foie Gras and Truffle Burger ($37.00) or the Rib Eye Steak Frites ($39.00) - and receive a free, refreshing brew - either meal will ensure its owner eats like a king on the one day a year to cherish doting dads.
The Father's Day menu is served alongside Rochford's Restaurant & Café menu - granting diners even more choice - the daily menu includes tasty dishes like Squid Ink Risotto, Wild Barramundi, Pumpkin Pappardelle, Blue Swimmer Crab Cakes and so much more.
Definitely book your seats ahead of time - the alfresco dining area will be open for diners to rejoice the return of spring - and the seats near the fire will be snatched up fast! Plan your trip accordingly - and leave some time to visit the Cellar Door for a complimentary tasting of some of Rochford's award-winning cool-climate wines.
Rochford Wines is less than an hour's drive from Melbourne - and a great place in the Yarra Valley to spend an afternoon with magnificent food and family this Father's Day - with views overlooking the vineyards and rolling hills of the Yarra Valley.

item.title: Greyt Greys & Friends Dog Walking Group
item.description:
Join other dog walkers on walks around the local area - all breeds welcome!
Greys and Friends has been set up for people owning rescued Greyhounds to connect with each other while enjoying walks in Mitchell Shire.
Walks are held on the last Sunday of every month (weather permitting). You and your dog need to be capable to walk approximately 1.5 hours and hopefully join the group for a coffee & chat at the end.

item.title: Tracking with the Pitcha Makin Fellaz
item.description:
Capture some native Australian animals through story and paint with the Pitcha Makin Fellaz.
First explore some Aboriginal stories about the Yarra River and the area outside ArtPlay, then meet the Fellaz (a group of seven Aboriginal men from Ballarat), find out how they create art together and try out some of their techniques.
You will make your own stamps out of foam and use paint to create patterns and imagery for a giant animal design which will be over 2 metres high! Twelve animal paintings completed by the Fellaz in collaboration with children at ArtPlay will feature in an exhibition from 29 October to 23 November 2014.
The Pitcha Makin Fellaz are: Myles Walsh, Peter-Shane Rotumah, Adrian Rigney, Ted Laxton, Thomas Marks, Billy Blackall and Joe Lee. Assisted by Peter Widmer.
This workshop is part of the ArtPlay New Ideas Lab where artists are supported to develop new work for children and families.
All children under eight years must be accompanied by an adult.
Fri 26 Sep and Wed 1 Oct. Exhibition launch party 3pm Sun 2 Nov.

item.title: Tom Evangelidis Façade Exhibition
item.description:
Façade by Sydney photographer Tom Evangelidis is an architectural photography exhibition shot in Prague, Bucharest, Hanoi, St Petersburg, Sofia, Istanbul and Havana over a 10-year period. Façade documents an eclectic mix of architectural eras, from the gothic beauty of the 13th century and the ornate decadence of the 18th century to the austere classicism of the Communist era in the 20th century.
As a photographer, Evangelidis is fascinated by the evolution of architecture and its intricate links with politics, culture and class. He approaches major public installations with the same respect as humble, ramshackle homes because he understands they are equally important in documenting the progression – and decline – of history.
Tom Evangelidis grew up along the northern beaches of Sydney. He made his debut as a fashion photographer in London in the early 1990s. Twelve years ago, Evangelidis shifted his focus to interior design and lifestyle photography, simultaneously travelling the world to pursue his passion for architecture.
Artist talk and book signing 4 Sep, 5pm-6pm, then opening event 6pm-8pm.

item.title: Our Shame – the Detention of Child Refugees
item.description:
Thousands of children are being held in immigration detention centres. Despite legal obligations to ensure the rights of these children are met, the Australian Government is being accused of depriving children of an education, adequate health care and exposing them to psychological and physical abuse.
Find out from some of Australia's leading exponents of legal, psychological, refugee and children's rights what is going on behind the fences of the detention centres that tax dollars are funding, and what we can do to ensure that the world's most vulnerable children get access to their basic rights.
Speakers include: - The Hon Alastair Nicholson AO, QC: Chair, Children's Rights International, Former Chief Justice, Family Court, Honorary Professorial Fellow, University of Melbourne.
- Professor Louise Newman AM: Professor of Developmental Psychiatry and Director of the Monash University Centre for Developmental Psychiatry & Psychology. Louise is the Convenor of the Alliance of Health Professions for Asylum Seekers and has held senior advisory roles to the Immigration Department.
- Dr Norman Gillespie: Chief Executive Officer, UNICEF Australia.
- Ms Katie Robertson: Associate, Maurice Blackburn Lawyers, currently working on a number of cases concerning the rights of asylum seekers in Australia.
- Mr Paul Power: Chief Executive Officer, Refugee Council of Australia.

item.title: Organ and Trombone
item.description:
An unusual and highly effective combination, Jennifer and Joseph display a shared sense of musicianship befitting a husband and wife duo.
Joseph Yu has played with the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra and the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra. He is Music Director of the John Mallinson Youth Band and conductor of the Moorabbin City Brass.
Jennifer Chou has performed as an organ soloist across the world, including at the esteemed Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris and Westminster Abbey in London. She is Director of Music at Toorak Uniting Church.
The program will include Leopold Mozart's Concerto for Alto Trombone, Alexandre Guilmant's Morceau Symphonique, Two Invocations by Petr Eben, excerpts from William Bolcom's Four Preludes on Jewish Melodies and Arthur Pryor's sumptuous Bluebells of Scotland.

item.title: Organ & Symphonic Band
item.description:
The musical might of Australia's military will be on display as the Air Force Band performs a Christmas-tinged program.
Favourites by Richard Strauss and Edward Elgar will be matched with lesser known works by Percy Grainger and Kenneth Alford. A highlight of this free concert will be the world premiere of a commissioned work by Melbourne composer Stuart Greenbaum.
The Air Force Band has a proud history dating more than 60 years. Its mission is to promote and enhance the image and culture of the Air Force through music and ceremony. Under the sixth director of music, Squadron Leader Mathew Shelley, the band regularly gives free public concerts as well as supporting the armed services both in Australia and abroad.

item.title: New Hypothetical Continents
item.description:
Melbourne-based artist Lucas Maddock will be exhibiting a sculptural installation over two weeks. New Hypothetical Continents maps the limits and contours of a fictional landmass as a lighting installation within this iconic Melbourne venue.
The work closely references an illustration from Lewis Spence's History of Atlantis and its subsequent appropriation by Robert Smithson in the wake of his failed Island of Broken Glass project. Maddock draws from colonial Australian landscape painting to explore the juncture between romantic idealism, atrocity and the quixotic pursuit of the utopic.
After hours viewings may be arranged by contacting the the Mission to Seafarers on (03) 9629 7083 or BlackArtProjects on 0421 990 481.

item.title: MSFW: Opening Night Shop–Hop
item.description:
Only a few days shy of spring, Melbourne Spring Fashion Week launches its extraordinary 2014 program with MSFW: Opening Night Shop-Hop on August 29.
Carrying the latest spring/summer collections, MSFW: Opening Night Shop-Hop Major Partner, Emporium Melbourne and Supporting Partners City Precinct, David Jones, Melbourne Central, H&M at Melbourne's GPO, Myer, QV Melbourne and The Strand Melbourne all open their doors till 10pm.
Revive your wardrobe with new season looks from your favourite stores and take advantage of the many exclusive retail offers available on the night. Check-out the brands you love on street runways and explore fantastic in-store activities. Eat out at Melbourne's celebrated food venues and experience roving entertainment.

item.title: MSFW: Hub
item.description:
Once more glorious City Square blooms with spring's green embrace and takes the name MSFW: Hub – the home of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week.
The perfect Melbourne experience, this temporary structure will play host to the best in fashion, retail, beauty, hospitality and live entertainment throughout MSFW. Take the lead from top brands and reinvent your spring/summer look. Check out free daily runways and try clothes on to fit at retail capsule collections.
Make the MSFW: Hub Bar your regular throughout the MSFW calendar. Work your way through an extensive lunch menu, delectable bar snacks and enticing desserts thanks to renowned chefs Gavin Baker (former sous chef at The Fat Duck) and Pete Evans (My Kitchen Rules judge) of Baker & Evans.
Enjoy the lively atmosphere and music with a variety of local artists playing DJ sets and live shows covering everything from pop and folk, to soul and RnB.

item.title: Melbourne Spring Fashion Week at Southgate
item.description:
Melbourne Spring Fashion Week (MSFW) arrives at Southgate with an eclectic range of free exhibitions and displays showcasing emerging designers.
Presented by the Photography Studies College, the Nixi Killick Centre Stage exhibition will be displayed in the podium-level alcove gallery. A collaborative photography exhibition between innovative emerging designer Nixi Killick and students from the multi-award-winning Photography Studies College, the exhibition showcases Nixi’s strikingly unique techno colour designs through one-off prints captured by some of the college’s most promising graduating students.
Nixi was recently chosen as one of the world’s top 100 independent designers at Italy’s Origin Passion and Beliefs showcase. Her designs are a vibrant mix of bio-psychedelic artwork and sculptured techno-wearables and have been worn by Lady Gaga, Kimbra, Hiatus Koyote and Lapalux of Brainfeeder. They have also featured on the runways of MSFW, Virgin Australia Melbourne Fashion Festival, AWARE and iD Fashion week.

item.title: I Wish I Could Keep Liking This
item.description:
Troy Mendham's practice as a painter encompasses that of the avid instagrammer and online content creator, who uploads imagery for online exchange, approximating aesthetic value with mass receivership. Rapid mash-ups of colour and line as well as a palpable sense of gusto distinguish his paintings.
As a painter-turned-image maker working through contemporary abstraction, his new solo exhibition 'I Wish I Could Keep Liking This and You Would Get Tonnes of Likes BC I Just Wanna Look at This 4 Eva!!!!' sees Mendham progress his exploration of new ways in which audiences are engaging in both physical and virtual arenas.
Mendham's engagement with the perpetual image stream of the screen follows on from his 'Ambush Exhibiting' series where he distributed his paintings in various public locations for audiences to find, document and re-appropriate as techno images using smartphones.
Mendham lives and works in Melbourne Australia and graduated with a Bachelor of Design from RMIT University in 1997. In 2011 he was a finalist in the St Michaels Archangel Art Prize, and in the same year won the Waverly Art Prize (Sydney) for drawing. Recent solo shows include Champion Breed at Seventh Gallery.

item.title: Hear the People Sing
item.description:
Whether you're a shower soloist or bedroom diva, come and join in this joyous community singing event inspired by the Victor Hugo: Les Misérables - From Page to Stage exhibition!
Learn the words and melody to the Les Misérables classic 'Do you hear the people sing?', then sing along with a massive community choir under the baton of original Australian Les Misérables cast member Martin Croft.
Performing on the State Library forecourt, the massed choir will be joined by special guest Chris Durling, currently starring in the Melbourne production of Les Misérables in the role of Enjolras, with piano accompaniment provided by musical director Vicky Jacobs.
To prepare for this celebratory event, download the lyrics and four-part harmonies, and start practicing.

item.title: Halloween Fright Night – Dis–organ–eyes
item.description:
The Night Terrors launch Pavor Nocturnus, a vinyl release (Dual Planet/Twisted Nerve Australia) that combines Grand Organ with theremin, drums and synthesisers. Quiet drops of sepulchral voltage and cacophonous whirls of intricate acoustic phenomena intermingle to prise open the maddening space between sentience and expiration. Miles Brown, Damian Coward and Sarah Lim combine to create a euphorically terrifying dream sequence, just perfect for Halloween.
Students from RMIT's Sculpture, Sound and Spatial Practice course will add to the drama with a series of short premieres in which the Grand Organ is triggered by computers. Pushing the boundaries beyond the humanly possible, expect to hear profound sub-bass, rippling sonic textures, and a précis of Melbourne's new sound of the decade ahead.

item.title: Glaucoma Community Information Forum
item.description:
The Centre for Eye Research is holding a community information session on glaucoma.
Glaucoma is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide, and one in ten Australians over 80 will develop this condition.
Learn about developments in glaucoma research and treatment from a leading ophthalmologist and researchers in this free forum.
Tea and coffee from 10:30am

item.title: Garage Sale Trail
item.description:
Garage Sale Trail is one big day of garage sales all around Australia.
This year's event will be held on Saturday October 25th and will be the world's biggest garage sale!
Garage Sale Trail is for households, community groups, schools, charities, makers and creators. So whether you have a yarn to tell or some yarn to sell, absolutely everyone can get involved!
Start by registering your Garage Sale at www.garagesaletrail.com.au! You can register a garage sale at your own home or business, or host a group sale with others at a local venue such as a school or community centre.
For some ideas and inspiration, check out our "How-to Guides" on the website for schools, community groups, local businesses and cultural institutions too, and get involved.
Bargain hunters can also create a Treasure Trail! It's an awesome way to save the Sales you want to visit and on the day you can print out a map to take with you, or access your Trail using your mobile device on the day. Start searching sales now to add to your trail and blaze away.
This event has been made locally possible by City of Melbourne.

item.title: Detective Special
item.description:
In her new series, Detective Special, artist Prudence Murphy builds upon her photographic inquiry into domestic rituals and the gestural acts of playtime by considering the role of social conditioning.
Photographically depicting fragments of guns and reflecting on their social significance and modes of operation, Detective Special conceptually shifts gears by moving away from Murphy's previous focus of playtime in the personal domestic realm to understanding its effects in society at large.
By presenting arsenal in lieu of their complete forms, Murphy's most recent body of work favours a fragmented approach to the documentation of her subject that intricately outlines the slippery terrain it occupies as a societal norm.
Prudence Murphy is based in Sydney and lectures at the University of NSW ' Art and Design. She has exhibited widely in Australia and was recently selected to exhibit in the 2014 Ulsan International Photography Festival in South Korea. She was a finalist in the 2014 Josephine Ulrick and Win Schubert Photography Award, 2013 Bowness Photography Prize, and the 37th Alice Art Prize. In 2007 she was short-listed for the Art and Australia Contemporary Art Award. Murphy's work is represented in national and private collections in Australia and overseas.

item.title: Deakin's Twilight Festival
item.description:
Join in the fun at the Deakin University, Burwood campus for a family friendly event, packed with free entertainment.
Fun on the day includes; fireworks, face painting, roving performers, petting farm, jumping castle, children's entertainment, fairy floss, popcorn and much more!
The fireworks spectacular will begin at dusk launching from our newest building right on Burwood Highway.
Food and beverages will be available to purchase from various stalls or you can visit the NEW family friendly restaurant Mrs Robinson.
Free car parking is available via Entrance 2.
Fireworks at dusk.

item.title: Chocolate Festival
item.description:
Acquire a better understanding and appreciation of fine Organic and Natural Chocolates by exposing yourself to the many different styles & varieties produced.
Stallholders include, Conscious Chocolate, Pana Chocolate, Pacari, Moo Free, Green & Blacks, RAW Chocolate, Alter Eco, Wholly Cacao, Sholuiku, Made With Raw Love, Ombar , Moo Free , Raw Chocolate Cheesecakes, Nuts about Life Chocolates, Rawsome Chocolates and more.

item.title: Bach's Back – Seniors Festival Organ Concert
item.description:
One of the greatest composers of all time regarded himself simply as a conscientious craftsman, doing his job as best he could in order to satisfy his employers, teach his equals and glorify God. Johann Sebastian Bach (1685-1750) would probably have been astounded to learn that 264 years after his death, his name is so revered.
Bon vivant Martin Setchell appears as master Baroque organist and composer Johann Sebastian Bach in an entertaining and educational theatrical performance in which the great composer introduces and plays his personal selection of favourite organ music, and reminisces about his life and times.
Martin Setchell is an English born, international concert organist, now based in Christchurch, New Zealand. Since 1997, he has been curator of the pipe organ in Christchurch Town Hall. He performs across the world with the express desire to perform music that entertains.
Doors open at 12:30pm.

item.title: Art n Music – Charity Exhibition
item.description:
A charity exhibition that features local and international artists, musicians, projectionists and designers with 100% of all profits donated to The Kids' Cancer Project.
The exhibition and entertainment includes works from artists, designers and photographers as well as an eclectic mix of live music from outstanding vocalists and acoustic musicians. A video projection display will also be featured, and drinks, nibbles and platters will be available throughout the night.
All profits will go towards helping to find a cure for children with cancer. Childhood cancer is one of the leading causes of disease related deaths. Survival rates remain low for many forms of childhood cancer. The Kids' Cancer Project is an organisation that is dedicated to finding a cure for childhood cancer and giving these children a second chance at life.
ARTISTS & PERFORMERS: If you'd like to exhibit or perform, please contact us on melb.social@gmail.com
Please get there early, as venue might reach capacity quickly.

item.title: AFL Grand Final Party
item.description:
Watch the game live and loud on the mega screen on the riverside promenade at The Wharf Hotel plus nine large plasma screens throughout the venue.
Complimentary drinks from first bounce till first goal!
Plus enter the competition to win the best seats in the house for you and four mates, a $200 bar tab, footy food and your own personal waiter for the day!

item.title: 3D Printing Showcase
item.description:
The purpose of this event is to bring together Victorian researchers, educators and enthusiasts with digital fabrication vendors to discover what the future holds for this amazing technology.
This is a chance to experience 3D printing up close and personal, and to hear from leaders in the fields, from researchers investigating new materials or new printer capabilities to sponsors showcasing cutting edge technologies. Additive manufacturing is growing at an incredible rate, and here is your chance to see what is coming in 2015 and beyond.
Commercial printing companies and research groups will be on display and there will be a series of lightning talks (10-20 minutes) on both days. Day one will be focussed on research and education, while day two will be a general public day with vendor talks.
There will also be prizes and giveaways and a sausage sizzle for lunch.

item.title: 18th Kenneth B Myer Lecture
item.description:
The speaker at this year's Kenneth B Myer Lecture is Professor Seth Grant from Edinburgh University, who will be speaking on 'Madness, Genius and the Origin of the Brain'.
Seth Grant graduated from Sydney University with a Bachelor of Science (Medicine) degree based on research in respiratory neurophysiology with Dr DJC Read in 1980.
He established his laboratory at the Centre for Genome Research at Edinburgh University in 1994 and in 2000 was appointed Professor of Molecular Neuroscience in the Division of Neuroscience. In 2003 he was appointed Principal Investigator at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute in Cambridge and remained there until 2011, when he returned to Edinburgh University.
The long-term aim of his research at Edinburgh University is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of behaviour and how these mechanisms are involved in brain disease.
The research has focussed on the study of genes and proteins that control the synapses between nerve cells. Multiprotein machines comprising many different protein components are responsible for basic innate and learned behaviours and dysfunction in many brain diseases.

item.title: Into the Spotlight - 2014 Hidden Faces of the Archibald exhibition
item.description:
Victorian artistic talent is revealed at its best in this year's Hidden Faces of the Archibald portrait exhibition with an extraordinary variety of subjects presented in an exciting diversity of styles and techniques.
The display is presented exclusively at the award-winning Hilton Melbourne South Wharf from August 18 to October 15, 2014.
Now well established in Melbourne's arts calendar, Hidden Faces, also known in art circles as the Victorian Salon des Refuses, unveils 43 exciting paintings of such well-known subjects as sports Icon: Paul Salmon; performers: 'Coxy' Dave Gray; artists: Godwin Bradbeer, Laurie Collins and Joseph Zhubvic; writers: Elliot Pearlman, Jenny Darling and Giles Parkinson; directors: Fred Schepisi and Richard Bence; politicians: Ted Baillieu and Joan KIrner AM and judiciary: The Honourable Tony Pagone, Geoffrey Robertson QC and Dr. Gregory Lyon QC.
There is something new and different each year and, now it its thirteenth year, Hidden faces continues to bring to the spotlight the amazing portraiture talent in Victoria. Artists include: Jacquie Blight, Jim van Geet, Ursula Theinert, Andrew Sibley, Polly Ifould, Annie On Lee, Dawn Stubbs, Ross Cockle, David Bryant,Victor Majzner, Steve May, Anna Minardo, Caroline Thew and Vicki Sullivan to name a few.
Hidden faces follows in the long tradition of the French Impressionists of the 1860s who held a breakaway exhibition from the reactionary French Academy. The inaugural Salon des Refuses, presided over by Napoleon III, included works by Manet, Cezanne and Whistler.
The People's Choice Award is a visitor's favourite with prizes provided by the Hilton Melbourne South Wharf.

image.altText: The arrival of the raven - Godwin Bradbeer
The arrival of the raven - Godwin Bradbeer
Voices in the Canopy - Victor Majzner
The right to the City - Kyle Magee
Still Opening Doors - Joan Kirner AM
Still Opening Doors - Joan Kirner AM

item.title: Prelim
item.description:
Prelim, a rarely seen collection of preliminary studies by Yarra Valley Open Studios artists including sketches, plans, visual diaries, models and maquettes.
Come and peak behind the curtain to find out more about local artists and their processes.
For a single weekend this spring, you are invited to experience the people, space, making process and ideas that unfold within the private studios of artists in the delightful Yarra Valley.
The 2014 program includes 43 inspiring artists, a group exhibition at Oakridge Winery, and a secondary exhibition, Prelim at The Memo.

item.title: Poetry of the Land - Painting by Deirdre Jack
item.description:
Poetry of the Land is a new exhibition at the East Gippsland Art Gallery, showcasing paintings by Deirdre Jack.
Deirdre Jack's subject is the land, the Alpine Region of the Great Divide of Victoria and Southern New South Wales.
In her paintings she speak of the land, its beauty and its strength which is evoked by its harshness. Deirdre aims to express a point of view that becomes an increasingly satisfying and poetic visual experience.

image.altText: Poetry of the Land - Painting by Deirdre Jack

item.title: Drawing Breath - Penny Carruthers
item.description:
Drawing Breath by Penny Carruthers is a visual and sensory response to the human face in all its diversity, the bringing to life, the drawing of breath with the physical and transcendent act of painting and drawing.
Drawing breath is also my metaphor for the anticipation experienced as each new work is commenced and conveyed from the conscious into scrutable form.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Raglan
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will get the chance to explore an interesting working farm, with substantial areas managed for conservation in Raglan Hills this spring, as part of Trust for Nature's annual Spring into Nature series.
Spot the beautiful wildflowers, plant species and wildlife that call this place home and learn how farming and conservation can co-exist.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Highcamp
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will get the chance to visit an interesting and accessible Trust for Nature owned property at Highcamp this spring as part of the annual Spring into Nature series. The walk will travel through a range of vegetation communities including woodlands, dry forests and open grasslands with spectacular views of the adjoining ranges and to Melbourne.
The Broken Creek Field Naturalist Club will lead the walk to highlight the natural values of the land and Trust for Nature staff will provide information on the benefits and responsibilities of owning conservation land protected by covenant.

address.address1: Corner of Crawfords Road and Back Creek Road

item.title: Spring Into Nature Trafalgar
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will have the chance to see first-hand the varied forest habitats that once covered the Strzelecki Range foothills when private conservation property, Uralla Nature Reserve, opens its gates this spring as part of Trust for Nature's annual Spring into Nature series.
Purchased with assistance from the RE Ross Trust, the Reserve is managed by Baw Baw Shire Council and Friends of Uralla Nature Reserve and supports endangered Shrubby Foothill Forest, Damp Forest, Strzelecki Warm Temperate Rainforest and a diverse range of flora and fauna.
Visitors can take part in activities throughout the day include a fauna survey display and discussion with wildlife ecologist Ann Williamson at 10:00am, guided nature walks and bird watching with naturalists and wildlife artist Nicolas Day at 11:00am and 1:30pm, and spotlighting for nocturnal wildlife dusk until late.
Attendees must RSVP and advise which part of the day they'd like to attend. All are welcome to come for part or all of the day and evening.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Boneo
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will be treated to a rare walk and talk around the privately owned Peninsula Gardens on the Mornington Peninsula with Dr Beth Gott, a renowned ethnobotanist, this spring as part of Trust for Nature's annual Spring into Nature event series.
As visitors walk through remnants of bushland (ranging from Heathy Woodlands to Warm Temperate Rainforest), Dr Gott will be will be guiding them through the traditional uses of some of the plants and the management of these ecosystems.
Visitors may even see kangaroos, a diversity of wildflowers and birds, as well as stunning grass-trees and fern gullies.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Kalimna West
item.description:
Come and enjoy the beauty of North Arm at Raki Raki, an area of high biodiversity and part of the internationally significant Gippsland Lakes. Be part of some great activities including a nature photography workshop, as well as view artworks by artist/printmaker Tama tk Favell - winner of the 2013 Darebin Art Prize.
Experience this magnificent area, home to a diverse range of flora and fauna including rare Warm Temperature Rainforest and a host of wetland birds.
Bring the kids along for Fishcare activities, as well as a free BBQ and opportunities to learn about land management initiatives including revegetation and control of tunnel erosion.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Gembrook
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts have the opportunity to join Trust for Nature on an exploratory walk and talk through a remarkable conservation property in Gembrook this spring as part of the annual 'Spring into Nature' event series. The walk will go deep into the magical fern gullies of the property to explore towering forests, moist gullies and spring flowers.
Visitors will also hear from wildlife expert Ed McNabb and his wife Susie about the land of Owls, Bandicoots and perhaps even see a Lyrebird.
Morning tea will be provided before venturing into the forests.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Killawarra
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will get the chance to take a guided hour and a half stroll through a beautiful privately owned woodland property in Killawarra this spring as part of Trust for Nature's annual 'Spring into Nature' series. The walk will be followed by a delicious afternoon tea (provided).
Wildflowers and woodland birds abound with several rare species recorded on the property including the Hooded Robin and Speckled Warbler. Visitors will learn about the recent woodland restoration techniques undertaken by the landowner in conjunction with Trust for Nature.

item.title: Spring Into Nature Kotta
item.description:
Nature enthusiasts will get the chance to visit one of Trust for Nature's protected grassland reserves on the Northern Plains near Kotta, west of Echuca, this spring as part of the annual 'Spring into Nature' series.
A section of the property was recently burnt to benefit native species and people will have a chance to learn about this management technique. Come for a guided walk through the property and hear about various projects underway to help protect the native grassland plants and wildlife. Hear from grassland experts and enjoy a morning tea and BBQ lunch on the day.

item.title: Percy Masters: A bonafide Gippsland Treasure
item.description:
The paintings of Percy Masters (1893- 1998) are greatly admired for their charm as much as their historical value.
Born in Walhalla in 1893, Masters spent a lifetime painting his memories of a youth growing up in the township. Today his works form an important account of the rise and fall of this early gold-mining town (which would later rise again).
Walhalla 150 Years marks 150 years of the town's foundation, and 100 years since the closure of the Long Tunnel Mine.

item.title: Murru
item.description:
Melbourne Festival and Big Hart in association with The Bardas Foundation bring you Murru.
Pilbara country is song country. In an uplifting opening concert for this year's Melbourne Festival, Big hART joins forces with a luminous range of talents - including Archie Roach, Lucky Oceans, Emma Donovan, John Bennett and many more - for a towering evening of song. MURRU is a musical tribute to John Pat, a young Yindjibarndi man who died in custody thirty years ago, sparking a royal commission and shining a spotlight on the increasing rates of Indigenous incarceration in our country.
Combining breathtaking imagery from the Pilbara region with beautiful harmonies and arrangements, co-written by inmates from the Roebourne prison, MURRU is an exuberant and heartbreaking celebration of our country - a hymn to the land and its people, a remembrance of those we've lost and a paean of hope for the future.
Directly before the Murru concert to mark the beginning of the 2014 Melbourne Festival, Federation Square hosts Tanderrum for a second year - a powerful event and celebration of the ground we stand on and of the people whose ancestors walked it before our time.
item.ns0:organiser: Melbourne Festival, Big Hart Association and the Bardas Foundation

item.title: Tanderrum
item.description:
Melbourne Festival and Ilbijerri Theatre Company in association with the Bardas Foundation bring you Tanderrum.
When, for the opening of last year's Melbourne Festival, elders of the five clans of the Kulin nation invited the people of Melbourne into their Tanderrum, it was the first such ceremony since the founding of modern Melbourne in 1835.
It was a proud symbol of the resilience and richness of Melbourne's Koorie history and culture, and a statement of optimism for the future.
This year's Festival once again commences with Tanderrum, a powerful event, deeply rooted in place and history - a celebration of the ground we stand on, and of the people whose ancestors walked it before our time.
The culmination of months of workshops between members of the five clans that make up the Kulin nation - Wurundjeri, Boonwurrung, Wathaurong, Taungerong and Dja Dja Wurrung - this powerful event invites all into their circle for a poignant exchange of story, song and dance.
Directly following the ceremony, Big hART stages Murru, an uplifting free concert in Federation Square.
The Ian Potter Centre: NGV Australia at Federation Square, Indigenous Galleries, Ground Level will be open until 9pm on Friday 10 October.
item.ns0:organiser: Melbourne Festival and the Ilbijerri Theatre Company

item.title: Nixi Killick Centre Stage Exhibition
item.description:
Nixi Killick Centre Stage exhibition presented by the Photography Studies College is a collaborative photography exhibition between innovative emerging designer Nixi Killick and students from the multi award winning Photography Studies College (Melbourne) showcasing Nixi's strikingly unique techno colour designs through one-off prints captured by some of the college's most promising graduating students.
Nixi was recently chosen as one of the world's top 100 independent designers at Italy's Origin Passion & Beliefs showcase. Her designs are a vibrant mix of bio-psychedelic artwork and sculptured techno-wearables and have been worn by Lady Gaga, Kimbra, Hiatus Koyote and Lapalux of Brainfeeder. They have also featured on the runways of the Melbourne Spring Fashion Week, Virgin Australia Melbourne Fashion Festival, Aware and iD Fashion week.
This creative and collaborative exhibition will be on display in the podium level alcove gallery at Southgate for the duration of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week.

item.title: Melbourne Spring Fashion Week at Southgate - Concept to Creation
item.description:
Presented as part of the Spring Fashion Week, Concept to Creation: Icons of Melbourne Design is an outdoor promenade exhibition.
The design ethos and inspirations behind seven of the city's most innovative designers will be uncovered in a unique outdoor exhibition on the Southgate Promenade.
Along the banks of the Yarra River opposite Flinders St Station, this exhibition will offer a sneak peek into the inspiration behind the designers' collections from 6pm on Friday 29 August. You can then see some of these designs come to life on runways as part of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week.
Featured designers include: Dom Bagnato, Gwendolynne, Richard Nylon, Feathers, Nicolangela, Tettmann Doust and Matcho Suba.
Concept to Creation provides an insight into the inner inspirations and musings behind the creation of these designers' Spring-Summer 2014 collections, as well as their unique personalities and the ethos behind their overall brand.
Discover more Melbourne Spring Fashion Week exhibitions, displays and fashion stores inside Southgate. Southgate is home to a range of boutique retailers including vintage and fair trade fashion, designer homewares, art deco jewellery and antique art situated amidst a diverse range of restaurants and bars.

image.altText: Melbourne Spring Fashion Week at Southgate - Concept to Creation
Melbourne Spring Fashion Week at Southgate - Concept to Creation

item.title: Sisely Estate Celebrates Spring
item.description:
A small family vineyard in the beautiful Yarra Valley will open its doors for three Sundays this Spring.
An opportunity to taste their range of full flavoured Preservative Free and Vegan Friendly wines and talk to the Winemaker in the perfect setting with wonderful views across to Mount Dandenong.
For more information, please contact Sisely Estate.

item.title: Children's Week - Healing Art Class for Kids
item.description:
As part of Children's Week come to Park Orchards House and Learning Centre for a free Healing Art Class for Kids!
A fun way for young artists to develop skills, enhance creativity, build self-esteem and nurture confidence. Bookings are essential for this free after school art class.
Time: 4pm to 5pm
A five week after school course commences the following week with print making, painting, collage, drawing and sculpture!

ns0:venue.name: Park Orchards Community House and Learning Centre

item.title: Children's Week Talk - Nutrition for Kids to Support Behaviour & Concentration
item.description:
Knowing what is best for kids to eat can be a minefield. Take the confusion out and learn about the most important foods and nutrients to give your kids the energy they need to make it through the day and improve your child's behaviour and learning.
Eating a nutrient rich but yummy diet supports optimal brain function and is one of the best methods for improving attention span and decreasing hyperactivity in children. Our Nutritionist has kid-friendly ideas that are easy, enjoyable and healthy.
The talk is from 7pm - 9pm at Domeney Recreation Reserve, Knees Road, Park Orchards.
Booking is required for this free event to Celebrate Children's Week!

ns0:venue.name: Park Orchards Community House & Learning Centre

item.title: Icons of Style
item.description:
Chadstone - The Fashion Capital and Australia's largest shopping destination welcomes the world's most stylish couple, Olivia Palermo and Johannes Huebl, to launch spring summer 2014 as their Icons of Style.
Launching the SS14 campaign with a series of iconic events Olivia and Johannes will make exclusive appearances at the Fashion Capital at the end of August, treating Chadstone Shoppers to their exclusive style and tips for achieving on trend looks this season.
Join Olivia and Johannes at this year's Chadstone's SS14 Runway featuring, Olivia Palermo's Australian Designer Edit - exclusively at Chadstone - The Fashion Capital.
Don't miss your exclusive opportunity to catch these international fashion icons.
With over 530 retailers and dedicated luxury, fashion, lifestyle and entertainment precincts; Chadstone is the ultimate destination for iconic style.
For more information on how to get involved visit the website.

item.title: Avenel Make it, Bake it, Grow it Market
item.description:
Traditional country market featuring local produce, plants, food and wine, kids activities, great coffee, community BBQ, live entertainment. Great day out for all the family.
Market is held second Sunday of every Month, so come and join in the fun of the fair and restock the pantry and enjoy a month of delicious deliciacies.

image.altText: Avenel Make it, Bake it, Grow it Market
Avenel Make it, Bake it, Grow it Market

item.title: A Secret Place
item.description:
If you fancy a 1950s New York vibe on your Saturday night, complete with romantic and spirited jazz, ice-cold cocktails and even a cigar room, you will want to book a table at A Secret Place, a members-only club that now opens to the public only on Saturday nights.
This Saturday features the Connie Lansberg Quartet.

item.title: World First Book Signing Session with Graeme Simsion
item.description:
Graeme Simsion's much anticipated sequel to his international bestseller, The Rosie Project, is to be released on Wednesday 24th September. The book, The Rosie Effect, is destined to be a bestseller as everyone who has read The Rosie Project cannot wait to re-engage with the characters.
Graeme will be at Reader's Feast Bookstore on the day of release at 1pm sharp to sign copies of The Rosie Effect.

item.title: Wear Art Thou
item.description:
No Vacancy Gallery will host a unique exhibition featuring over 50 new designs by Illustrators Australia members. Wear Art Thou will be the culmination of a new venture between Illustrators Australia and the online artist marketplace, Redbubble. Redbubble challenged Illustrator Australia members to create designs specifically for t-shirts and will present the results in this exciting exhibition.
Wear Art Thou will feature the works of Illustrator Australia members from across the nation, including a new t-shirt design from each artist as well as other works displayed on a range of mediums, from wall art to throw pillows. In addition, the exhibition will be supported by t-shirt connoisseur Eddie Zammit, who will attend the opening night on Friday 5 September to award a people's choice award.
Opening night Friday 5 September, 6pm to 8pm.

item.title: The Future is Here
item.description:
The Future is Here is a touring exhibition created by the Design Museum, London, focusing on new techniques, technologies and relationships.
When on show at RMIT Design Hub, the exhibition will include additional local design research projects that demonstrate the importance of speculation and prototyping to innovation and design.
The world is in the midst of a transformation in the way it designs, makes and consumes the objects that everyone depend upon. New techniques, technologies and relationships mean that the boundaries between designer, manufacturer and user are becoming increasingly blurred.
The Future is Here asks what that means for all.

item.title: The Australian Red Cross in the Great War
item.description:
Celebrate 100 years of the Red Cross in Australia with this stunning photographic exhibition.
Featured in the exhibition are striking images from the Australian Red Cross archives – most on public display for the first time – that convey the nerve-centre of the Australian Red Cross in Melbourne. The exhibition also looks at Australian Red Cross fund-raising efforts in Victoria and their compassionate projects at home and abroad.
Presented by the Royal Historical Society of Victoria.

item.title: Social Conscience and the Popular Novel
item.description:
Victor Hugo, Leo Tolstoy, Harriet Beecher Stowe and Charles Dickens were all bestselling authors of their time – Hugo’s Les Misérables sold 6000 copies a day when it was published in 1862.
Each of these writers touched on themes of repression, poverty and political unrest in their novels. Did they deliberately tap into the current concerns of the day or were they just producing gripping good yarns?
Join author and freelance literary writer Jane Sullivan as she chairs a lively and entertaining discussion about the 19th-century novel and the social conscience.
Panellists include historian Anna Welch, who worked as the assistant curator on the State Library's exhibition Victor Hugo: Les Misérables – From Page to Stage, and world-renowned translator Julie Rose, whose translation of Victor Hugo's Les Misérables is the first full original unabridged English translation of the book.

item.title: Silhouette
item.description:
Silhouette is a night that focuses on artists that complement and match each other's sound, styles and musical direction with visual imagery to suit.
Playing at Loop for this next installment of Silhouette will be Kaysh, Lexis Laqua, Smack Bass, Andre Le Vogue and very special guest DJ Masahito (Tokyo). Pixel Angel will supply the amazing visuals.
This event is a gathering of creative minds, a celebration of music and art in a venue that caters just for that.

item.title: Page Not Found exhibition
item.description:
The famous Sands & McDougall Victorian Directory was the internet of its day, a vast web of information compiling the names of Melburnian householders in enormous annually published volumes. Today, its 117-year publishing legacy - and the great beauty of the huge books - is immense.
Founded in 1857, the Directory of residents, trades and streets lasted until 1974. It remains much-used by historians and genealogists - but also contains many lost and unexpected treasures. Page Not Found explores how each Directory is a story of lost Melbourne, for every year's volume records the massive changes this city has undergone.
The exhibition is curated by arts journalist Andrew Stephens and features illustrations by Oslo Davis.

item.title: On the Paths of the Heart – Sui Sentieri del Cuore
item.description:
Through his images, music and poetry Alessandro Carta guides the audience in an atmospheric journey of soul-searching. Alessandro will share his two lives, the Italian and the Australian, by recollecting and reciting poems accumulated over more than thirty years, punctuated by instrumental interludes composed and played by the author himself. All poems will be recited in both English and Italian.
The evening will be introduced by Dott. Francesco Pascalis, and also feature M.Mangione and G.Campomizzi.
There will be a Q&A session at the end of the evening, and the book 'Sui Sentieri del Cuore - On the Paths of the Heart' will be available to purchase on the night.
Alessandro Carta was born in Rome in 1952. He graduated in painting at the Academy of Fine Arts in Rome in 1975 where he started to experiment with painting, graphics, poetry and music. He migrated to Brisbane in 1985 where, after a few years spent in the building industry, he resumed his artistic vocation. In 1991 he became part of the Queensland Multicultural Writers while teaching Italian to the elderly and the disabled. In 1994 he completed a Postgraduate Diploma in Education and became a teacher of Italian language in primary schools with the Department of Education of Queensland. A car accident in 1995 forced him to resign from this position and he has since taught Italian at the Institute of Modern Languages (University of Queensland) and engaged in musical and artistic endeavours.

item.title: NICTA Tech Showcase
item.description:
NICTA's annual technology showcase is a must-see event offering the opportunity to view NICTA's latest ICT research and technology demonstrations and see the results from collaborative projects with industry.
Meet Victorian university partners, thought leaders, researchers, PhD students and technology experts and see how critical issues for Australia's future are being addresses in the areas of: infrastructure, transport and logistics; broadband and the digital economy; and security and environment.
NICTA's Tech Showcase is co-exhibiting with the National iAwards and Australia 3.0 Forum, in partnership with the AIIA, ACS and the Pearcey Foundation.

item.title: Melbourne Social Club Drinks Night
item.description:
Come along and enjoy an end-of-the-month drinks night at the Word Lounge Bar, hosted by the Melbourne social club 'Fun, Food and Friendship'.
This free event is open to everyone, with drinks available at bar prices, so come along, meet some of the hosts and club members and start enjoying a great social life.

item.title: Melbourne Day Lecture
item.description:
What is your personal culture map of Melbourne? How has it changed over time? Come along to the annual lecture to commemorate Melbourne's birthday, held by the Royal Historical Society of Victoria.
In this forum, prominent speakers Reuben Berg and Richard Broome share their understanding of Melbourne across time and space.

item.title: Marvel Exhibition – The 2014 Windsor Prize
item.description:
Victorian College of the Arts students will transform Melbourne's Windsor Hotel into a public gallery while vying for The Windsor Art Award, a scholarship recognising Australia's best emerging talent.
Opening on Melbourne Day, 30 August, the Marvel exhibition and Windsor Art Award will be judged by a prestigious panel including Heide Museum of Modern Art director Jason Smith and artist Julia DeVille.
As part of a collaborative exhibition between the VCA's School of Art and the landmark hotel, visual art students will install works that are conceptual and material interpretations of the theme 'marvel'.
The installations will feature in many of the hotel's unique spaces, including the heritage-listed lace iron lifts, Victorian windows, renowned tea room and even a once secret hotel entrance.

item.title: Junior Rangers – The Bee's Sneeze
item.description:
Springtime is upon us and once again the air is filled with nature's wheezy, sneezy golden dust. Celebrate spring by joining the City of Melbourne Park Rangers for a fun-filled day of games and activities that explore the hidden world of pollen and pollinators in Royal Park.
Program runs Wednesday, Thursday and Friday only.

item.title: Japan Dolphins Day
item.description:
Join Australia for Dolphins as we celebrate Japan Dolphins Day on the St Kilda foreshore with a free event on the 31st of August 2014.
