We will be celebrating all things dolphin related with a number of fun and family-friendly events including live music, face-painting, street performers, dancing, sand-sculpting, a colouring in competition, chocolate, and other dolphin-themed surprises!
They will be in the middle of the foreshore (near Stokehouse) from 12pm. Just look for the dolphins!

item.title: Indigenous Literacy Day at Melbourne Library Service
item.description:
Melbourne Library Service and the Indigenous Literacy Foundation celebrate Indigenous Literacy Day, a national celebration that raises awareness about literacy in remote Indigenous communities.
Money raised at these events will go to the Indigenous Literacy Foundation to buy books for children and families in remote Australian communities.
There will be a fundraising book sale at City Library and Southbank Library at Boyd, Acoustica play in the City Library Gallery and see Leann Edwards, indigenous author of 'Emu's Under the Bed' paint the City Library Mural.
See timetable on website.

item.title: Inaugural Professorial Lecture – Professor Sujeeva Setunge
item.description: Civil infrastructure assets such as bridges, buildings, storm water networks, sewer pipes, seaports and rail lines deliver essential services required for functioning of a society. Many of these structures in the world are over their design life. However, replacement of these are often challenging due to many reasons such as cost, disturbance to other structures and interruptions to service delivery. Professor Sujeeva Setunge, from School of Civil, Environmental and Chemical Engineering, RMIT University will present outcomes from a number of research projects, a diverse range of approaches used to derive deterioration models and optimised management strategies for Civil infrastructure assets will be presented. The work presented will cover four major infrastructure sectors: buildings, bridges, sewers and seaports.

item.title: Hidden in Plain Sight: Jane Austen Today
item.description:
Enjoy a series of talks and papers discussing Jane Austen in today's world.
Leading Austen scholar John Wiltshire offers new interpretations of Jane Austen's work. Writer and academic Kylie Mirmohamadi will speak about her new book about Austen spin-off fiction, and Clara Tuite from the University of Melbourne will speak about 'Great Myths of Jane Austen'.
The event will feature the launch of two new books on Jane Austen: John Wiltshire's The Hidden Jane Austen (Cambridge University Press) and Kylie Mirmohamadi's The Digital Afterlives of Jane Austen (Palgrave Pivot).
Refreshments will be served.
Launches begin at 4pm.

item.title: Genesis for Atheists: Contemporary Hermeneutical Methods
item.description:
The Atheist Society is hosting a public lecture on 'Genesis for Atheists: Contemporary Hermeneutical Methods' with Rev Dr Paul Tonson from the Uniting Church in Australia. The lecture will be followed by questions and discussion.
The Atheist Society is for atheists, agnostics and free thinkers who agree to disagree.
Coffee and conversation from 7pm.

item.title: Forum: Performing Social Justice
item.description:
Theatre and performance makers are invited to participate in a 'Theatre of the Oppressed' forum. Working with Augusto Boal's techniques, Shahin Shafaei will lead the group in exploring, naming and reclaiming some of the challenges faced in creating performances around social justice and change.
Shahin Shafaei is an Iranian-Australian storyteller, writer, director and 'Forum' theatre practitioner. Raised and nurtured through the theatre scenes of Iran, he has written and created over a dozen large scale performances in his mother tongue. In the year 2000, political situations put an abrupt end to his creative endeavours in Iran and Shahin moved to a new continent, exploring a new language along with new mediums for his storytelling. He has a strong passion for social dialogue and human stories, which for the best part of the past decade, has empowered him to work with people from a multitude of backgrounds and in a variety of settings, within Australia and overseas.
Presented by the Institute of Postcolonial Studies in association with Tribal Soul Arts.

item.title: Carlton Italian Festa
item.description:
Carlton Italian Festa is a fun free day of activities celebrating the food, art, music and culture of Italy!
It is about bringing all Melburnians - young, old and in between - together in the heart of Melbourne's Italian precinct to celebrate all things Italian.
The day will feature music, dance and comedy performances along with cooking demonstrations, sporting and children's activities. There will also be lots of delicious Italian food and drinks available for purchase.

item.title: Bloom
item.description:
Internationally renowned architect Alisa Andrasek will be a special guest of Design Hub, in partnership with RMIT School of Architecture and Design. Andrasek's interactive installation Bloom will be on show in conjunction with The Future is Here, an exhibition touring from the London Design Museum.
The urban toy, distributed social game and collective 'gardening' experience was first installed in London as part of the capital's city-wide celebration during the 2012 Olympics and Paralympics. Bloom seeks the engagement of people to construct its organic, blooming formations - so come to Design Hub and play!
Bloom is designed and developed by Alisa Andrasek and Jose Sanchez from The Bartlett School of Architecture at UCL.
The Future is Here will be accompanied by a full program of associated talks and workshops, including an opportunity for local Melbourne design firms to come and play with Bloom.

item.title: Believe in Belief
item.description:
Enjoy an evocative portrayal of spiritual beliefs in Lanna (Northern Thailand) through dance and workshops.
Believe in Belief is presented by a Melbourne-based Northern Thai (Lanna) contemporary artist, an award-winning sculptor, and an independent contemporary composer from Thailand and Lanna.
The event is led by Nakarin Jaikla, a Melbourne-based Lanna contemporary artist and features Pimpisa Tinpalit's sculpture art. This exhibition includes a contemporary dance performance and craft-art workshops and exhibits the way people believe and worship sacred supernatural beings.
Special guests include Ronnarong Khampha and Thitipol Kanteewong. The event is directed and choreographed by Nakarin Jaikla.
This project is supported by the City of Melbourne 2014 Arts Grants Program.
Free workshops on Saturday and Sunday at 1pm and 2.30pm. See website for more details.

item.title: Adornment
item.description:
Adornment, 'the act or process of making someone or something attractive by decorating', is the theme for the latest collection on display at Lord Coconut during Melbourne Spring Fashion Week.
For as long as human beings have existed, we have sought to adorn ourselves to display status and beauty. Temporary ornaments such as jewellery and permanent markings including tattoos have been observed since before recorded history.
Animal bones have played a special role in adornment from hunter-gatherer times until now. In ancient China they were decorated with inscriptions and put to the flame in a practice of divination; a way of communicating with their gods. Many cultures believe people embody the traits of different animals.
Lord Coconut is presenting a new take on this time-honoured tradition.
Jewellers, artisans and designers have been given a found bone and instructed to adorn it in a masculine way, or use the bone when producing a piece of adornment for men, especially jewellery. The resulting works will be featured in the Adornment exhibition, as a comment on the current explosion of body adornment, both permanent and temporary, seen in fashion today.
Participating jewellers and artist include Ali Alexander, Melissa Baldock, Emily Becher, Dianne Beevers, Beth Croce, Patricia Denis, Amanda Fox, Max Honigsberg, Emma Luke, Dan McGill, Fiona Meller, Jason Paterson, Suse Scholem, Aimee Sutanto and Roxanne Watts.

item.title: Active and Well After Breast Cancer
item.description:
Women from Melbourne's North West who have had breast cancer are invited to attend Breast Cancer Network Australia's (BCNA) free 'Active and Well After Breast Cancer' information day.
Designed for women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer up to three years ago, the information day will help women to improve their health and well-being following treatment for breast cancer.
The event will highlight the importance of physical activity and healthy eating after a breast cancer diagnosis, as well as provide practical strategies to help women embark on a healthier lifestyle.
The program will feature the latest information and advice from exercise and nutrition specialists, inspiration from Olympian and breast cancer survivor Raelene Boyle, and opportunities to meet other women who want to get more active.
Arrive 9am for 9.30am start.

item.title: Majlis Travelling Scholarship: Exhibition
item.description:
The Majlis Travelling Scholarship is open to third (final) year undergraduate students at the VCA's School of Art.
A travelling scholarship of $10,000 will be awarded to a third-year student and will allow the scholarship recipient to travel overseas at the conclusion of their undergraduate studies.
This keenly anticipated exhibition of shortlisted works provides a snapshot of student activity within the VCA School of Art.
Participating artists include Nina Ambjerg-Pedersen, Lauren Berkeley, Caroline Collom, Theia Connell, Ann Debono, Majed Fayad, Olivia Floate, Imogen Henry, Paula Hunt, Aodhan Madden, Ilya Milstein, Rohan Noonan, Jamie O'Connell, Natalie Philipatos, Jake Preval, Matthew Vaughan and Karen Wells.

item.title: Bayside Wedding Expo
item.description:
Plan your wedding in a day by the bay at The Brighton Savoy on Sunday 14th September 2014 from 11am - 3pm. With over $5000 worth of prize's to be given away on the day.
Register online today.
The Bayside Wedding Group is a group of like-minded, locally based businesses dedicated to offering professional wedding services operating in the Melbourne Bayside area.
The biggest day of your life needs the biggest celebration of your life too. Brighton Savoy takes care to immaculately plan every step of the way and creates the ambience you've always dreamt of for your wedding.
Whether it is an intimate beach wedding ceremony or an elegant affair indoors, we can back you up in every little detail. For beach ceremonies, we create an alternative indoor space too just to keep your anxiety about any weather changes at bay. From exquisite decor to divine food, we can cover every aspect of the wedding.

item.title: Yarra Valley Spring Festival
item.description:
The Yarra Valley Spring Festival is a family friendly festival with unique products and stalls.
With gorgeous clothes and crafts, beautiful food and wares, free kids activities, live music, rides and more, it's a great day out for the whole family.
Located in Seville - a small town in the heart of the Yarra Valley - take a drive out and enjoy some organic foods, local produce and unique giftwares.
The Yarra Valley Spring Festival is a community run event - all proceeds go back to benefit the community.
Take a drive out to the small town of Seville and have a lovely day enjoying all we have to offer.

item.title: Creative Crafts Demonstration at Queen Victoria Market
item.description:
Join artist Edith JoChinke from Timeless Treasures Cottage Crafts at Queen Victoria Market for craft demonstration.
Edith will show you the step by step process of creating a beautiful desk organiser from scratch, using decoupage techniques and paper embellishments. You can use these simple scrap booking technique to personalise many such products in your home. A perfect way to update your home decor this Spring
Every participant will go in a draw to win a beautiful gingerbread cottage kit worth $20.00.
Every participant also receives a free gift from Timeless Treasures Cottage Crafts product range.
Demonstration will run from 10:30am to 11:30am.

address.address1: Timeless Treasures Cottage Crafts Container 11, String Bean Alley

item.title: Stockroom Selection- August
item.description:
From August this year Cambridge Studio Gallery is starting the first of their new stockroom exhibitions.
Artists are more than painters, they experiment and test ideas as well as explore alternative mediums. Thus the gallery has selected interesting works from artists that have had a history with the gallery as well as promoting some interesting new artists. There will be an eclectic selection of paintings, sculpture, jewellery and a few surprises!
While the gallery's business model still represents artists by providing space for their exhibitions, there will be value adding to the viewer experience by dedicating the upstairs gallery space to the Stockroom Selection. Works will be displayed in a less formal "salon-hang" that allows clients to purchase and take home works on the day.
Some of the artists in the August Stockroom Selection include, Ness Alexandra, Otto Boron, Sara Catena, Susan Gibson, Sharyn Madders, Beatrice Magalotti, Kitty O'Kane, Rosemarie Reber, Elinor Ryan, Jenny Scholes, Emma Vasilisa, Erica Wagner, Paul Walsh and Beryl White.

item.title: Artist Floor Talk By Wayne Viney
item.description:
Join the Hamilton Art Gallery for a floor talk by artist Wayne Viney as he discusses his latest exhibition Singular Impressions, currently on display at Hamilton Art Gallery.
For more than thirty years Wayne has been absorbed with the production of paintings and prints that reference the Victorian landscape. He has managed to combine these two techniques with great mastery and with the use of a printmaking press produce what is referred to as monotypes - meaning literally one print.
The Greater Hamilton community is invited to come and meet the artist and enjoy a pleasant social winters morning at the gallery, including a light morning tea. Local schools and art enthusiasts are particularly encouraged to attend to learn more about the relatively uncommon medium of monotypes.
Singular Impressions will be on display at Hamilton Art Gallery until the end of August.

image.altText: ARTIST FLOOR TALK BY WAYNE VINEY
ARTIST FLOOR TALK BY WAYNE VINEY

item.title: Vin Ryan - Dirt World
item.description:
Vin Ryan has invited his family, friends and various acquaintances to sweep the floors of their houses, collect their sweepings; the discarded, dirt, grime and dust, and submit these sweepings to the artist for aesthetic consideration. The collective effort of this strange request will be presented in Ryan's upcoming solo exhibition Dirt World.
Ryan believes that with each sweep, contained within each dustpan, is a memorial - a sample of life - as revealing as a diary.
The stuff we sweep up might speak to us about ourselves in any number of ways but one thing's for sure - we don't want other people to see it. Nothing motivates the desire to sweep the floor more than the possibility of imminent visitors. To sweep is to remove shame. - Vin Ryan
Dirt World will feature a selection of Vin Ryan's photographs of these potentially exposing and surprisingly beautiful sweepings. Through the exhibition the viewer is invited to peruse the dust created by others, both abject and attractive, and to consider their own detritus.

item.title: Nature Through My Eyes - Photography Exhibition
item.description:
Monash Gallery of Art is delighted to present this exhibition of works by Peter Kinchington an award winning nature and scientific photographer.
He has always been inspired by nature and photography as a medium that lets him share his wonder with others.
In his exhibition Nature Through My Eyes he has given a taste of Australia's diversity of life with wonderful and unique wildlife and landscapes from small insects to sulphur crested cockatoos. The techniques used to capture his vision of nature include infra-red, underwater and macro photography using specialised cameras and lenses.
He would like to share with you the wonder that he has for Australian wildlife and inspire you to look after the natural heritage for children and children to come.
Peter Kinchington wishes to thank the City of Monash for this opportunity to share his work and to thank his family both past and present for their support and inspiration.

image.altText: Nature Through My Eyes - Photography Exhibition
Nature Through My Eyes - Photography Exhibition

item.title: Back to Steiglitz Festival
item.description:
The Back to Steiglitz Festival is a fabulous old fashioned family fun day is out. As aptly quirky as the little ghost town itself, there's something to delight everyone: gold panning, a blacksmith, stalls, kids games, country baking, guided walking tour, musicians, engines, lace making, raffles, competitions, barbecue, historical displays, the famous action-packed Steiglitz Billy Cart Race, and more.
Win a helicopter ride, or one of two beautifully restored treadle sewing machines!
Free entry and old fashioned prices. All proceeds from a Back to Steiglitz stall or activity helps preserve the town's historic public buildings.
Set in the last Victorian town without electricity, this isn't just a fundraiser or simply a reunion, it's a reflection of a wider community, one where your support makes a world of difference.
Buy a snag and help the Maude C.F.A. Devonshire tea helps the Anakie PFA assist their kids education. Entering the Billy Cart Race broadening the horizons of local scouts. High tea at Peppercorn Place Café supports a wonderful woman. Visiting the Steiglitz Historical Society's Museum will inspire their volunteers and and enjoying home cooking from Sugg's blacksmith's cottage will help the BTS paint St. Paul's Church.
So come on everyone, let's all get behind this terrific little event! Remember, the Back to Steiglitz Festival is put on by a group of volunteers and they don't just raise money, but are about socialising, sharing skills, fun, respect, friendship, and above all oodles of laughter. So if you think you'd like some great adventures, could work a one to two hour shift, then you'll find yourself a welcome member of this award winning association.
See website for full program details.

image.altText: The main street of Steiglitz Township
The main street of Steiglitz Township

item.title: Entreprenuer Intensive Seminar
item.description:
The internationally acclaimed Entrepreneur Intensive, hailed as the most powerful two days of business training in the world and facilitated by business expert Wilson Luna, is a unique platform specifically designed to give entrepreneurs the opportunity to access world-class mentoring and business acceleration strategies.
The seminar will be help in Melbourne on 23 August at 9:00am until 24 August 5:00pm. Booking your seat is essential as it books out

item.title: all that glitters...Art Exhibition
item.description:
Brian Reberger, Melbourne Artist, presents his solo exhibition of his recent Art works. The exhibition is titled: all that glitters.....inspiration from Italy and beyond.
This exciting exhibition features works inspired by Italy, Berlin, Prague, India and Vietnam.
With this latest collection of charcoal paintings he has incorporated either gold or silver leaf in each image giving extra depth and another dimension to the light in the works. Homage is paid to the Italian masters Bernini, Cellini and the ancient tradition of the use of gold leaf on religious paintings, altarpieces and church decoration, adding my personal modern perspective.
This free exhibition highlights personal moments that will resonate deeply with the viewer.

item.title: Meet the Alpacas at Creswick Natural Fibres in Daylesford
item.description:
With the cooler months, it can be a challenge to find something a little different to keep your kids entertained. Why not bring them to the Creswick Natural Fibre store in Dayelsford to meet the alpaca family?
Did you know that alpacas belong to the same family as camels? These gentle animals communicate by humming and love chasing each other up and down the paddock. They are very inquisitive and enjoy being patted and fed.
Come any time to pat and mingle with our Alpaca friends, they are very friendly and soft! This is an opportunity to meet the friendly alpaca family members in Daylesford. Entry is free. There is just no reason to miss it.

item.title: Meet Alpacas in Sassafras
item.description:
With the cooler months, it can be a challenge to find something a little different to keep your kids entertained. Why not bring them to the Creswick Natural Fibre store in Sassafras to meet the alpaca family?
Did you know that alpacas belong to the same family as camels? These gentle animals communicate by humming and love chasing each other up and down the paddock. They are very inquisitive and enjoy being patted and fed.
Come any time to pat and mingle with the Alpaca friends, they are very friendly and soft! This is an opportunity to meet the friendly alpaca family members in the Dandenongs. Entry is free. There is just no reason to miss it.

item.title: Victor Hugo: Les Misérables – From Page to Stage panel discussion: Social conscience and the popular novel – Hugo, Dickens, Tolstoy and Stowe
item.description:
Victor Hugo, Leo Tolstoy, Harriet Beecher Stowe and Charles Dickens were all bestselling authors of their time - Hugo's Les Misérables sold 6000 copies a day when it was published in 1862.
Each of these writers touched on themes of repression, poverty and political unrest in their novels. Did they deliberately tap into the current concerns of the day or were they just producing gripping good yarns?
Join author and freelance literary writer Jane Sullivan as she chairs a lively and entertaining discussion about the 19th-century novel and the social conscience.
Panellists include historian Anna Welch, who worked as the assistant curator on our exhibition Victor Hugo: Les Misérables - From Page to Stage, and world-renowned translator Julie Rose. Julie's 2008 translation of Les Misérables is the first full original unabridged English translation of the book.

item.title: Lunchtime Concerts at Melba Hall
item.description:
Come down for a series of lunch hour concerts hosted in the newly refurbished Melba Hall, held each Monday of semester.
Featured artists include. Jacinta Dennett, Melina van Leeuwin and Michelle Doyle on the Harp, Brendan Lunkin on the organs, Alvin Won on the cello, Kristian Chong on the piano and much more.
For a full list of performers or more information, please see website.

ns0:venue.name: Melbourne Conservatorium of Music, Melba Hall

item.ns0:organiser: Melbourne Conservatorium of Music, University of Melbourne

item.title: Rising: The Victoria Harbour Young Artist Initiative
item.description:
In its seventh year, Rising: the Victoria Harbour Young Artist Initiative is an exhibition of public artworks from young artists currently studying in Sculpture & Spatial Practice, School of Art, Victorian College of the Arts, The University of Melbourne. It offers these artists at the commencement of their careers an opportunity to experience the challenges and rewards of developing and exhibiting major works for public spaces.
Featuring Artists include, Carla Milentis & Madeleine Mills, Georgia Knight & Julia Dunne, Madison Kelly, Amy Robinson and Riley Richardson.
Curated and coordinated by Laura Woodward with Sarah Jane Haywood.
The 2014 artworks include an interactive work involving mirrored surfaces, a sculptural version of a shipping container, a rainbow lighting installation, a diving board emerging from the water and a performance piece involving semaphore flags that will occur at lunchtime each day.
Rising: the Victoria Harbour Young Artist Initiative 2014 is jointly presented by Sculpture & Spatial Practice, School of Art, Victorian College of the Arts, The University of Melbourne, and Lend Lease, with support from Parks Victoria.
The exhibition will be opened by Professor Barry Conyngham, Dean, Faculty of VCA & MCM, The University of Melbourne.
Open every day on the Victoria Harbour Promenade at the corner of Merchant St, Docklands.

image.altText: Rising: The Victoria Harbour Young Artist Initiative 2014
Rising: The Victoria Harbour Young Artist Initiative 2014

item.ns0:organiser: School of Art, Victorian College of the Arts, University of Melbourne

item.title: Majlis Travelling Scholarship: Exhibition
item.description:
The Majlis Travelling Scholarship is open to third (final) year undergraduate students at the VCA's School of Art.
A travelling scholarship of $10,000 will be awarded to a third year student and will allow the scholarship recipient to travel overseas at the conclusion of their undergraduate studies. This exhibition of shortlisted works is keenly anticipated, and provides a snapshot of student activity within the VCA School of Art.
Featured artists: Nina Ambjerg-Pedersen, Lauren Berkeley, Caroline Collom, Theia Connell, Ann Debono, Majed Fayad, Olivia Floate, Imogen Henry, Paula Hunt, Aodhan Madden, Ilya Milstein, Rohan Noonan, Jamie O'Connell, Natalie Philipatos, Jake Preval, Matthew Vaughan, Karen Wells.
item.ns0:organiser: Margaret Lawrence Gallery, Victorian College of the Arts

item.title: Penshurst Community Market
item.description:
Penshurst is set at the base of Mount Rouse in Western Victoria. Come along to the Penshurst Community Market for a variety of stalls including fresh fish, fruit and vegetables, cheese, olives, honey, local wine, books, an array of crafts, adult & children's clothing, chocolates, plants, biscuits, cakes, jams and other preserves.
This year the Market introduces a new area 'Art at the Market' with all style of artist work from around the district to be displayed and for sale.
Local bands will keep you entertained while you enjoy a sausage sizzle, and kids can enjoy some time on the jumping castle.
New stall holders welcome.

item.title: French Amazing Race
item.description:
Embark on a French adventure: follow a trail and explore St Kilda! Race against the clock to follow clues and find the answers for your chance to win!
Two races have been designed so that both young and old alike can enjoy their day.
Great prizes to be won, see website for more information.

item.title: Awkwood Book Launch
item.description:
Milk Shadow Books and Squishface Studio are proud to be launching Awkwood, the long awaited debut graphic novel from Jase Harper. Free beers will be flowing thanks to Stone & Wood Brewing.
Awkwood is the story of a young man overcoming his inner and outer demons, and a giant monster, whilst building a path to his true love, music.
Jase is legendary Australia-wide for his high quality gig posters, animation work and of course, Guh!, his long running mini-comic series.
Come past and get your book signed and sketched in by Jase. There'll also be a small number of packs available containing the hand made screen print that Jase has created to celebrate the launch.
Drinks, beer and nice things to eat will be provided, including special Awkwood-themed cakes/treats. Jase will also be displaying some of the original pages and art from the book too.

item.title: Tatong Village Market
item.description:
Tatong Village Village Market, located in the grounds of the historic Tatong Tavern Hotel, provides an excellent country setting for a local food sampling and gathering experience, offering the perfect start to a weekend of local sports, a visit to the slopes or whiling away time in front of open fires enjoying local wine, great food and good company.
The Tatong Village Market will showcase an array of fresh produce, food and wine in addition to a country breakfast fit for a king! Produce to be expected includes fresh fruit and vegetables, free range pork, olives and oil, free range eggs, walnuts, including pickled walnuts, beef, mutton, plants and herbs, organic bread, culinary rose product including home made Turkish delight and quince jelly, fine tea, cakes, biscuits, tarts, homemade soaps, relishes, chutneys and wine produced in nearby Samaria and Lima.

item.title: Open Studios Nicholas Building
item.description:
This year the Nicholas Building Open Studios event is celebrating its 10 year anniversary. Started in 2004 this intimate twilight event gives you a behind-the-scenes glimpse of Melbourne's thriving art and craft culture.
Visit specialist retail spaces, galleries and meet the artists and designers that make up this extraordinary high-rise community.
This is your opportunity to engage with artists and commission or purchase original Melbourne made and designed art, fashion, jewelry and bags within the vibrant and unique creative hub that is the Nicholas Building
Some of the artists throwing open their doors are jeweller Vikki Kassioras, milliner Serena Linderman and book sculptor Nicholas Jones.

item.title: Bright & Loud
item.description: Bright & Loud brings the North East Skate Series Bright heat and mixes it with the best live music from local and national musicians. Join them for a night of awesome music and impressive skate, scoot and BMX skills. Entry is free. This is a drug and alcohol free event.

item.title: Stitching Stories Quilt Exhibition
item.description:
Contemporary Art and Traditional Quilts featuring diverse quilting techniques and each with its own unique story to tell on display in this gorgeous array of quilts. Quilt exhibitions are usually about the quilt. Today, quilts are not only valued for comfort but have become a means of expression as a form of textile art. This exhibition is about the stories of the individual quilt maker.
Eleven outstanding Victorian Quilters display their top creations - ranging from the most traditional through to the most contemporary, in this wonderful Collection of 'the art of the quilt'.
Linda Bear, Lesley Goddard, Anne Sushames and Toni Warrell work in the traditional style of patterns & imagery. Dijanne Cevaal, Felicity Griffin Clark, Susan Mathews, Sarah Louise Ricketts, Robina Summers, Olga Walters and Fiona Wright are amongst Australia's foremost Contemporary Art Quilters. They have exhibited internationally many times and their quilts are in numerous Australian and overseas collections.
Stitching Stories is an inspiring exhibition which shows how beautifully quilts can tell stories through stitching.

item.title: What I Have to Do/What I Would Like to Do
item.description:
Cristian Iotti, a professional photographer from Reggio Emilia in Italy, lived in Melbourne from November 2013 to July 2014. During this period he became interested in the experiences and difficulties of the many young Italians who, after having arrived in Melbourne, find themselves making a living by undertaking all manner of jobs. Often these jobs are far from glamorous and are part of that compromise which is demanded by any country of immigration. This, however, has never kept these resourceful young people from engaging in and pursuing their individual passions.
Cristian Iotti's photographic exhibition portrays both the resilience of young Italians in Melbourne, working hard in order to make a living, and their undaunted desire to turn their dreams into reality.

item.title: Tricky Traps
item.description:
The incredible design and engineering feat of the spiders' web will become an object of wonder and inspiration when ArtPlay is transformed by a delicate tangle of webs with the installation of Tricky Traps. Visitors will be encouraged to reconsider the workings of these tiniest of creatures that help make the amazing world that we live in. Carefully wander through this tricky environment and find a space to create your own artwork. Make an insect pod from string, do a drawing or craft a spider sculpture.
Age: 4 to 12 years
Free, no bookings required
All children must be accompanied by an adult.

item.title: The Langham – Melbourne Bridal Showcase
item.description:
The Langham, Melbourne is located right in the heart of Melbourne's vibrant Southbank precinct overlooking the city skyline and Yarra River. With experience in hosting more than 80 weddings per year, the hotel's events experts will be available to assist in answering questions and providing tailored information for engaged couples and their families. Guests may even sample dishes from Executive Chef, Anthony Ross's bespoke wedding menus.
The hotel chairs will be bowed with different knots and the table centerpieces will glisten under the Clarendon Ballroom's sparkling Wedgwood crystal chandeliers. The warm timber finishing and contrasting table settings will provide couples with an accurate visualization of how The Langham, Melbourne can assist in making their dream day a reality.
Boasting an open terrace on the 25th floor overlooking the Melbourne CBD and Yarra River, Alto is the perfect private venue for a contemporary, classic or vintage-style wedding. The abundance of natural light combined with customized styling of the room is a unique place to say 'I do'.
Each room will display an array of all-inclusive centerpieces, chair covers, sashes and table linens complemented by the intricate stationery of Papyrus Designs.
Intimate spaces, such as the The Yarra Room and Flinders Room, will be ready-set for a smaller wedding and ceremony space and accommodation rooms will also be available to view.

item.title: Tape It!
item.description:
Imagine a drawing that has become bored of paper and wandered off the page in search of new adventure. If this sounds appealing, drop into ArtPlay for Tape It!, a collaborative, room-size, expanded drawing made of lines of colourful electrical tape. Everyone of all ages can contribute to the artwork which may expand in many creative directions and dimensions.
There will also be some very simple rules to guide those who would like to learn about generative art. All materials will be provided. The drawing will run most of the day that is, until the un-drawing stage begins! Sometimes deconstruction is just another stage of creation. Find out how when you come along to Tape It!
Age: Family
Free, no bookings required.

item.title: Stitching Stories Quilt Exhibition
item.description:
Contemporary Art & Traditional Quilts featuring diverse quilting techniques & each with its own unique story to tell on display in this gorgeous array of quilts.
Quilt exhibitions are usually about the quilt. Today, quilts are not only valued for comfort but have become a means of expression as a form of textile art. This exhibition is about the stories of the individual quiltmaker.
Eleven outstanding Victorian Quilters display their top creations - ranging from the most traditional through to the most contemporary, in this wonderful Collection of 'the art of the quilt'.

item.title: Spring Fling Street Festival
item.description:
Head down to Errol Street on Sunday 19 October for North Melbourne's premier community event, the Spring Fling Festival.
You will enjoy a free day for the whole family with live music, interactive kid's activities, a new vintage and handmade artists market, multicultural performances and the famous Spring Fling Dog Show.
Brought to the community by the Centre, with the help of public partner City of Melbourne and major sponsor Yarra Trams.

item.title: Polish Festival
item.description:
The Polish Festival at Federation Square celebrates ten years of bringing a taste of Poland to Melbourne.
The festival celebrates Polish customs and tradition. Federation Square is filled with various examples of Polish culture closely connected with the country's intricate thousand-year history - whether delectable cuisine, folkloric entertainment, examples of Polish wares or unique craft work.
The festival's aim is to ignite a little bit of the Polish in every one who visits on the day.
So come along and see what everyone's talking about. It is well known that when two or more Poles get together you are sure to have a good time, but when a whole community gathers you know that things are going to be electric.

item.title: PhD Up and Comers
item.description:
From the bionic eye to the ethics of stem cell tourism in China, meet the next crop of neuroscience-related PhD students.
On show are four diverse, multidisciplinary and innovative projects and the students behind them will deliver engaging presentations on their ideas.
This event is chaired by Professor Dick Strugnell, Pro Vice-Chancellor (Graduate Research).
The presentations include the following:
'A Need to Know: the Neural Substrates of Information Seeking' by Daniel Bennett, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences.
'Stem Cell tourism to China', by Jane Brophy, Stem Cells Australia.
'Stimulation control of bionic eye' by Matias Maturana, Melbourne School of Engineering.
'Do you hear what I hear?' by Krysta Callendar, Melbourne School of Psychological Sciences.
Presented by the Melbourne Neuroscience Institute, University of Melbourne.

item.title: One Planet
item.description:
The Wilderness Society and Urban Screens Productions is presenting a panel discussion on the future of Australia's natural environment.
The interactive discussion will explore ideas around nature being an intrinsic part of Australian life and identity. We live, work, and play in the great outdoors, but what will Australia's nature look like in 50 years time?
If you would like to ask the panellists any questions, register now. The discussion will be followed by a screening of the feature documentary Planet Ocean.

item.title: Nietzsche, Freud, Lacan: Real Ethics
item.description:
The Existentialist Society's free monthly public lecture program is for those who question whether life has a meaning and a purpose.
This month, Dr Tim Themi from Deakin University and the Lacan Circle of Melbourne will present a lecture entitled 'Nietzsche, Freud, Lacan: Real Ethics', followed by an extended period of questions and discussion.
First Tuesday of every month, except January.

item.title: Melbourne Zoo – Wedding Open Day
item.description:
Take a stroll through the beautiful zoo grounds and discover the stunning ceremony locations and reception venues at Melbourne Zoo.
All ceremony locations and reception venues will be fully set up for this day with an array of centrepieces and linen to choose from. Guided tours will operate every hour starting in the Leopard Lodge, with the opportunity for guests to take a self-guided tour as well. Enjoy complimentary refreshments and sample delicious canapés as you meet with a range of wedding suppliers who will be exhibiting on the day.
You will also have the opportunity to meet with the zoo's weddings team who are committed to assisting you create a unique wedding that you and your guests will remember for years to come.
You'll also have the chance to take advantage of the special offers available on the day, including a complimentary wedding ceremony package valued at $2,000.

item.title: Melbourne Social Club Drinks Night
item.description:
Enjoy an end-of-the-month social drinks night at the Apartment, hosted by the Melbourne Social Club 'Fun, Food and Friendship'.
This event is open to everyone and is free to attend, with drinks available to purchase at bar prices. Members receive a free drink as part of their membership.
The Melbourne Social Club has reserved space at the popular Melbourne bar, the Apartment. Designed as an extension of a living room, it is a cosy and suave establishment with plush couches, sheer curtains and designer fittings. It is a great place to enjoy the company of friends in a familiar yet modern environment with good old-fashioned, friendly hospitality, which makes it an ideal location for this social drinks night.
If you are not a member, book in and meet some of the hosts and members, learn more about the best and liveliest social activities in Melbourne and start enjoying a great social life.
For more information on the events and benefits of the Melbourne Social Club 'Fun, Food and Friendship', visit the website.

item.title: Kwave Festival
item.description:
Immerse yourself in Korea's rich culture at K Wave Festival 2014.
Some of the best Korean restaurants in Melbourne will be serving Korean dishes, and performances on the main stage will feature home-grown talent covering songs and dances from popular Korean artists. See Korea's traditional Hanbok dress and be amazed by the strength and discipline involved in a Taekwondo showcase. There'll also be stalls stocked with the latest Korean dramas, variety shows, merchandise and CDs.
Do you consider yourself a K-Pop fan? Then get involved and show support for your favourite artist in an epic battle of the fans.
This year's event also features a Q&A with special guest Eric Nam, an up-coming Korean-American artist making waves in Korea.

item.title: iLearn: iPad Essentials
item.description:
Get the most out of your iPad. Learn how to set it up, all about apps and other great iPad features as well as how to get started on social media. Bring your own iPad or use one of theirs.
The workshop runs the first Thursday of the month from 11am to 12pm (4 September, 2 October, 6 November, 4 December).
No prior skills are necessary.

item.title: Footy Colours Day at Fed Square
item.description:
You're invited to a Footy Colours Day spectacular! For the first time, Fight Cancer Foundation is hosting a family fun day at Fed Square to celebrate Footy Colours Day.
Wear your team's colours and join in a myriad of free activities for both young and old.
There will be freestyle football, handball competitions, an ice cream van, face painting, balloon twisting, live stage shows, footy mascots and so much more!

item.title: Font Factory
item.description:
Workers are needed to create a font out of nothing but rubbish. Use recycled materials to make an R out of bottle caps or an M out of sticks, put it on the factory line, and watch it be turned into a font that you can type with. What crazy letters can be made? We need your help to make every letter in the alphabet. Make a letter or simply have fun typing messages to your friends and family using the Font Factory font.
This is a free, with no bookings required. l children must be accompanied by an adult.

item.title: Festival of Colours Celebration
item.description:
Th wonderful, playful, sensory experience of Holi is a vibrant celebration of tradition and truth. Participants bless one another by throwing, smearing and showering each other in brightly coloured powders.
If you can’t make it for the Festival of Colours workshop (visit the ArtPlay website for more details), then come along for the celebration which will include a performance of traditional Indian dancing, rituals and the famous Holi colour throwing. (All powders will be made from natural, non-toxic ingredients.)
For ages 5-12 years. All children under eight years must be accompanied by an adult.
Starts at 3pm sharp.

item.title: Family art-ivity: Where Sport Meets Art
item.description:
Held at the Ian Potter Museum of Art, in each workshop families will enjoy a tour of the exhibition, before making their own artwork inspired by a special blend of art and sport.
Culture Mamas was established in 2012 by two art-loving mums and lifelong friends, Rebecca Asp and Claire McClelland.
Committed to helping parents connect to the very best arts and culture in Melbourne, Culture Mamas encourages mums dads and carers to connect with the arts to stimulate their intellect and connect with a supportive network of like-minded souls.

ns0:venue.name: The Ian Potter Museum of Art

item.title: Encryption
item.description:
Encryption is an exploration of photographic code and language via the visual narrative by 34 student photographers from Melbourne's CATC Design School.
The collective body of work features ideas and themes inspired by the land, the object, the portrait and dreams/visions. The name embodies the work as a whole and relates to the cryptic language of photography in all its forms. It also suits the wonderful exhibition venue, the basement gallery of the Donkey Wheel House, a mysterious crypt-like subterranean space located at the western end of Bourke Street.
Each student will be presenting a series that may provide a peephole into the exhibitor's personal life, or make a statement about a social or environmental issue. The works on show will be diverse, visceral and thought provoking.
Encryption is supported by Gold Street Studios, Third's Fine Art Printing, Paper Lab Co, PhoNRoll Café, Majestic Cakery, Art Du Jour, Ricci Jean Make-up, Let's Get Even Hairdressing, Woolworths and Donkey Wheel House.

item.title: Bunjil Mithidha Nanyuk – Bunjil’s Cave Myth and Legend
item.description:
Bunjil Mithidha: nanyuk (Bunjil's cave: myth & legend) is a solo art installation by Lee Darroch, Yorta Yorta, Mutti Mutti, Boon Wurrung artist.
This installation explores some of the south-eastern Aboriginal creation stories. These particular creation stories were documented by the first curator at Melbourne Museum, Aldo Massola. Before Massola's time some of these creation stories were told by Aboriginal people in the 1800s to R. Brough Smythe and A.W Howitt. These creation stories form the basis for some of the creation stories told in Aboriginal Victoria today.
'Bunjil Mithidha: nanyuk (Bunjil's cave: myth & legend)' creates sculptures from the earth, lakes and the sea to tell our stories. The creation stories depicted use found objects from the lakes and ocean where Lee lives including shark eggs, shells, driftwood, bull kelp, sand and ochre.
The art installation is made up of many different sculptural elements around the theme of creation stories. Elements include a spiral of life, Bunjil's eaglehawk nest, driftwood sculptures depicting the men and the women of the 38 tribes of Victoria, possum bags, armbands, kangaroo cloaklet and so on.
The stories on the 'Dhamala Biganga (grandfather cloak)' were passed on to Lee by her father before he passed on. The cloak is for Lee's children and children's children as a 'family teaching cloak' to learn about their grandfather and their Yorta Yorta country.
Lee urges all Aboriginal parents, grandparents and Elders to pass the creation stories from their mob onto the next generation. 'This wealth of knowledge and rich identity needs to be continuously passed on to make children proud and strong in who they are and where they come from' she says.

item.title: Brad Sugars Uncensored
item.description:
Held at the Sofitel Hotel Melbourne, you are invited to Brad Sugars inspirations show; Uncensored. The event can immediately give you real tangible strategies on how to grow your business globally and build real wealth for yourself!
Register for your seat online. For full program details, please refer to website.

item.title: Asthma Take Control
item.description:
Singer/songwriter Kimbra is joining forces with asthma experts and key respiratory health organisations to help to launch the Asthma Take Control campaign.
The event runs from 7am until 2pm and Kimbra will kick off the campaign with a special performance at 8:15am. You can make a lung health pledge that will go to create a one-day art installation, plus there'll be asthma educators on hand doing on-the-spot asthma checks. Just look for the pair of giant inflatable lungs!

item.title: ArtPlay Backyard
item.description:
ArtPlay will have all sorts of materials on hand for you to create your artwork. Draw in the sand, build sculptures with recycled and natural materials or muck about with water. Make a mandala, wrap up some rope or ribbon and dream up your own mini landscape. Anything is possible!
Don't forget to wear appropriate clothes and bring a rain coat. The program will run whatever the weather!
Free, no bookings required. All children must be accompanied by an adult.

item.title: AFL Grand Final: Footy Free Zone
item.description:
Ditch the boys and forget the AFL footy finals this year at Campari House! Gather the girls for afternoon drinks on the Rooftop, then continue the party in the Lounge Room with Mamma Got Soul in the evening.
For more information or to make a booking, please refer to website.

item.title: The Contact Print
item.description:
The Contact Print is an exhibition of images captured using a large format view camera and hand-printed using traditional palladium/platinum and photogravure processes.
In these prints, the landscape and architecture of Central Victoria have been beautifully preserved and printed in methods that capture the delicate detail and tonality of these subjects.
Stephen Tester is a fine art photographer and printmaker. He has a passion for landscape photography and is attracted to photograph those places he connects to and engages with. His use of film, particularly with large format view cameras, and hand coated papers using palladium, platinum and gold provides the means to create unique, individual photographs unconstrained by proprietary processes. Living in central Victoria Stephen is attracted to the historic nature of the architecture of the the gold rush period that continues to define the characteristics of many towns today.

item.title: Whitehorse Song Project
item.description:
Whitehorse Song Project; write a song and record in a recording studio!
Take part in an exciting community project where you will work with professional songwriter Eva Popov, a music producer and film-maker to create an original song and clip that celebrates what home means to you. This is open to all members of the community. Find your creative voice and experience the joy of making and sharing music with others.
August 10 - Songwriting August 17 - Songwriting August 24 - Rehearsal and Recording Prep. August 30 - Recording at Studio
Bookings Essential

item.title: Threaded Journey
item.description: The Threaded Journey exhibition, focusing on the importance of the string bag, brings together husband and wife team Naup Waup, Papua New Guinean artist and Lisa Waup, Torres Strait Islander and Gunditjmara decent artist. Lisa was recently included in the highly successful and defining Melbourne Now Exhibition at the National Gallery of Victoria.

item.title: The 4 Peace Band
item.description:
The 4 Peace Band playing the great tunes from the sixties to the nineties. Featuring Paul O Gorman who had the sensational seventies Hit Ride Ride America.
Some great vocals and great musicians make for a fun night out of singing and dancing.
Cost: Free Entry Time: 8pm to late

item.title: Burnley Information Day
item.description:
Australia's best horticulture and environmental management courses - at your fingertips. At the Burnley Information Day you'll have the opportunity to speak to current students and researchers focussed on sustainable gardening and horticultural practice at Melbourne's famous heritage-listed Burnley Gardens, which celebrated its 150 year anniversary in 2013.
Burnley Information Day offers activities include:
- Garden tour with current students - Green roof tour - Mini lectures on arboriculture, garden design and green roofs - Student & alumni panel - University of Melbourne Commercial - explore professional short courses - Course Expo
For a campus map and further information on how to reach Burnley, please visit the website.
Time: 12pm to 7pm

ns0:venue.name: The University of Melbourne, Burnley Campus

item.title: Victorian Schools Music Festival
item.description:
In August young musicians from across Victoria and interstate will take part in the annual Victorian School Music Festival.
Over 3000 band members will perform at the Festival, which runs day and night for 8 day at Deakin Edge, Federation Square. The musicians are from 130 concert bands representing 80 schools from throughout Victoria and interstate.
Each ensemble performs works from a prescribed list and then participates in an on-stage "master class" with the chief adjudicator immediately after their performance. The Victorian School Music Festival offers students an excellent opportunity to compare their own performance skills with those of their peers. Although there are no outright "winners" of the Festival, all bands will receive awards reflecting their quality of performance at Platinum, Gold, Silver and Bronze.
Chief adjudicator for the 2014 VSMF is American Dr. Gary Sousa, Director of Bands and Professor of Music at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. As Director of Bands, Professor Sousa conducts the University of Tennessee Wind Ensemble, teaches graduate courses in conducting and repertoire, directs the Masters program in Wind Conducting, and oversees the entire band program.
The Victorian School Music Festival is produced by Fine Music Hawthorn. Other major sponsors include Federation Square, Hal Leonard Australia Music Foundation and Yamaha Music Australia.

item.title: Photography Expo
item.description:
Come and enjoy seeing magnificent photographs by Wendy Clark of Master Your Camera. There will be a range of subjects, including nature, flowers, landscapes, people, animals and travel.
Talks and Demonstrations on photography techniques will run at 11am, 1pm and 2.30pm. Subjects are photographing flowers, how to photograph people and photographing small creatures. Bring your camera to get the most out of it.
There is a chance to win some photography tuition and information on a variety of photography classes.

item.title: Cartoonist Q&A
item.description:
Join the Burrinja Gallery for a lively Q&A session with three of the exhibiting cartoonist from the She'll be right, mate? - An Indigenous History in Australian Cartoons currently on show at Burrinja Gallery.
Burrinja Gallery are inviting you to bring your burning questions about cartooning to the discussion: How do cartoonists see the world? What is it like caricaturing prominent and political figures? How to structure a cartoon? Do get cartoonists hate-mail?
Panel includes:
Rolf Heimann (LOFO): Melbourne based Heimann has published over 70 books since the mid-1970s and is the man behind the Eagle Eyes Books published in the late 1980s. He was named Australian Cartoonist of the Year at the 19th Annual Stan Cross Awards in 2003, for cartooning excellence.
Bronwyn Halls: Physicist turned cartoonist, Bronwyn Halls is one of the few female artists to make a living from the profession. She has worked for the Melbourne Times and many other papers since the late 1980s.
Paul Harvey (Harv): A sports cartoonists for many years, Harvey is well-known for his cartoons of AFL players. With a wealth of knowledge around the practice and an impressive back-catalogue of caricature stories, expect to hear some great tales.
Facilitated by Jim Bridges, President of the Australian Cartoon Museum
Free entry, however places are limited, so please RSVP your attendance.

item.title: One Planet
item.description:
The Wilderness Society and Urban Screens Productions bring you the One Planet Event - an interactive panel discussion on the future of Australia's natural environment.
Join the legendary conservationist, Dr Jane Goodall and experts from all over the world to talk about our environment.
Who: Dr Jane Goodall - world-renowned conservationist and UN Messenger of Peace Amanda McKenzie - CEO, The Climate Council Glen Klatovsky - Director, Places you Love Jeff Smith - Executive Director, Environmental Defenders Office NSW Dermot O'Gormon - CEO, WWF Australia
What: An interactive discussion on - Nature has always been an intrinsic part of Australian life and identity. We live, work, and play in the great outdoors. But, what will Australia's nature look like in 50 years' time?
If you want to ask our panellists any questions - register now! The discussion will be followed by a screening of feature documentary Planet Ocean at 3pm EST.
When: 12pm (attend in person) and 1.30pm (online screening)
Register online.

item.title: Yarra Primary School Fete
item.description:
Yarra Primary School's fete promises to be bigger than ever this year! Come along and enjoy all the fun of live music and acts, great food and drinks, rides and entertainment, for the whole family!
Simply because Yarra Primary believe a great fete should not only have good activities and good food, but also, good music.
This fantastic event is about celebrating and showcasing our wonderful school and bringing people together, especially those from the local community, for an experience extravaganza of fabulous food, drink and music along with picking up bargains from pre-loved books, or new hand made items from our craft market stalls and delicious organic produce from the kitchen garden.
Anyone who wishes to have a great community day out is more than welcome along.
For the children or young-at-heart, there are rides, giant chess, splash dunker, fairy floss, face painting, woodworking, kid's craft, bush baby animals, and much, much more!
The money raised from the Fete goes directly to the education of the children at Yarra Primary School.
Like many small schools we rely on additional funding to maximise the learning opportunities for our children and our fete is the school's major annual fundraising event.
Although the day is primarily a community building event, with the help and generosity of local businesses and community, the funds raised on the day goes directly to the educational needs of the children through extracurricular program upgrades, otherwise unfunded, such as Kitchen Garden Program, ICT (Information & Communication Technology) equipment, and purchasing the latest literacy assisted learning sets.

item.title: hillsceneLIVE
item.description:
hillsceneLIVE is two things in one; A mini-festival of Performance and Live Art and the launch of the Hillscene magazine Spring issue.
It is a new event presenting artists from diverse practices performing work that is bold, striking, risky or experimental.
Capacity is strictly limited, so reserve your ticket now!
The inaugural event received overwhelming support and attendance. hillsceneLIVE number two, is set to be bigger and bolder than the first. The mini-festival will take over the Belgrave Township, with performances taking place in a range of re-invigorated and re-imagined spaces: empty shop fronts, kooky corners, underground lairs, public thoroughfares and cafes.
Armed with a map of Belgrave, audiences meet at Belgrave station, and are then asked to seek out, explore and find a number of secret locations in the township. At these locations, audiences are treated to experimental performances from some of Dandenong Ranges' most exciting artists! hillsceneLIVE supports the ambitious, the bold, the risky and the brave. Come along on a fanciful journey of live art and performance, and experience Belgrave as you never have before.

item.title: Full Moon Festival
item.description:
The Mid-Autumn Festival (known as mooncake festival) is an official harvest festival celebrated by over 10 countries within the Asian region. The festival is held on the fifteenth day of the eighth month in the Chinese calendar, during a full moon, which is in September.
This festival is held in Dandenong Market and will bring together numerous communities who celebrate this annual occasion. There will be numerous authentic food stalls from nations celebrating and they include China, Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Korea, Taiwan, Philippines, Indonesia, Cambodia, Japan and other surrounding countries.
There will also be numerous kids activities including lantern making, mooncake eating competition and numerous other activities for kids. This event is held during the Dandenong Market Week and will be an event not to be missed.
Enjoy the numerous food selections and savour the taste of street food and cultural performances.

item.title: Women's Health Week Launch
item.description:
Jean Hailes Women's Health Week is an opportunity to learn about health and confidence with a host of women's health experts and celebrity ambassadors.
Visit the Swanston Street forecourt, say hello and take part in the fun. Make the most of the giveaways, show bags, free health information and entertainment. You can also find out about events, join competitions and share what confidence means to you.

item.title: William Angliss Institute Open Day
item.description:
Join the passionate staff, students and industry partners at William Angliss Institute (WAI) for this year's action-packed Open Day on Sunday 24 August.
Prospective students and community members are welcomed to explore the institute's world-class industry training facilities and experience a taste of WAI's programs, career opportunities and life on campus.
Two of Australia's most distinctive culinary talents, Shangri-La Hotel Sydney Executive Pastry Chef Anna Polyviou and owner and Executive Chef of Melbourne's The European, Ian Curley, will be there for first-class cooking demonstrations and interacting with future students.
Register early for the 'Trial a Trade' sessions where you can gain hands-on experience as a patissier, chef, baker, beauty therapist or events manager.
Other exciting activities include: spa tasters, butchery competitions, affogato and latte art demonstrations and a social media competition
The day is perfect for students looking for a job away from the desk, where you can learn from industry experts and start your career before you finish studying - it all starts at William Angliss Institute.

item.title: Uncommon Places
item.description:
In 2014, Melbourne Fringe has commissioned emerging artists to create visionary site-specific work in City of Melbourne for the festival’s Creative Program Keynote Project – Uncommon Places.
The project explores the concept of the 'Third Place' – meaning not home or the workplace, but special locations where people gather, converse, catch up and hang out. These places stitch the fabric of society together; they are informal sites that foster civic engagement, political thought, multicultural vibrancy and a sense of belonging.
Artists have been invited to celebrate Third Places across Melbourne, to show what they mean to the communities that visit them. The project runs at various locations across the city for the duration of the Melbourne Fringe Festival.
See melbournefringe.com.au for schedule.

item.title: The Vivisector
item.description:
Andrew Delaney strips the human condition bare in The Vivisector.
In the guise of The Vivisector artist Andrew Delaney declares the human condition stripped bare, reaches into its hollowed cavity and extracts the very stuff from which we are made. Figures and objects fashioned from foundational fabrics and structural textiles represent the artist’s commentary on how we contend with being ourselves.
The Vivisector is a literal and figurative flaying of our fragile attempts at being human – offered with restorative empathy. Empathy is instantly conveyed by the sense of touch – it creates intrinsic connections. The textile nature of Delaney’s works in The Vivisector evokes this and allows us to explore even the most confronting of material.
Launch night Tues 26 Aug, 6pm to 8pm

item.title: The Better City – Sustainable Living in Urban Australia
item.description:
Join the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne Philip Freier, urban planner Professor Roz Hansen and Lord Mayor of Melbourne Robert Doyle as they discuss the infrastructure, social justice and ecological challenges facing growing cities.
Sponsored by The Melbourne Anglican Foundation, Anglicare Victoria, The Brotherhood of St Laurence and The Melbourne Anglican.

item.title: Science Makes Melbourne Cool: Astonishing Facts and Stories
item.description:
Melbourne Conversations joins with the Club Melbourne Ambassador Program during National Science Week to celebrate science and technology and tell the 'cool' stories of past Melbourne scientific achievements and possible future breakthroughs.
Melbourne, long recognised as the arts and culture capital of Australia, also has amazing scientific and technological credentials that are earning the city a similar reputation worldwide. Celebrate National Science Week and the potential of science and technology with a sample of our very best and brightest brains as they inject stimulating factual stories into the conversation.
Expect discussion on how scientists are solving problems, the science behind discoveries plus breaking news on the latest achievements and innovations.
Developed with the general public in mind, it will also be of interest to the professional. Come along, join in come and get your hard questions answered.
Panel: Dr Krystal Evans – CEO BioMelbourne, Melbourne Assoc. Prof. Christopher Fluke – Centre for Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University of Technology Dr Cathy Foley – Deputy Director Manufacturing Flagship, CSIRO and Engineering and Club Melbourne Ambassador Ms Bridie Smith – Science Editor, The Age, Melbourne Emeritus Prof. Alan Trounson – Monash University and Club Melbourne Ambassador
Host: Niall Byrne – Creative Director, Science in Public, and Club Melbourne Ambassador
A Melbourne Conversations event developed in partnership with Club Melbourne Ambassador Program, Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre and National Science Week with support from Future Leaders and Knowledge Melbourne – an initiative of the City of Melbourne
Doors open at 5.30pm.

item.title: Marini Ferlazzo Exhibition
item.description:
Founded in 2011 by mother and son creatives Clare and Nathan Ferlazzo, Marini Ferlazzo is a label that combines art and fashion with a focus on sophisticated, luxury classics that are carefully tailored using natural fibres. Each piece is designed and handmade in Australia. Nathan's artworks create uniquely designed fabrics found nowhere else in the world, with each garment individually numbered and limited. Marini Ferlazzo donates 5 percent from every sale to organisations supporting environmental and wildlife conservation.
As part of Melbourne Spring Fashion Week 2014, you are invited to join Clare and Nathan at the opening night of their first public exhibition since launching in 2013. Champagne, beer and canapés will be provided. Nathan and Clare will be present over both exhibition days to meet visitors.
See the original artworks in their fine detail and touch the beautiful silks, linens and wools of the handcrafted, limited-edition garments. Clothing and artwork will be available to purchase on the night. You will also have the chance to try your hand at pen-and-ink illustration with the traditional nib, ink and cotton rag that Nathan uses to bring his artworks to life.
Ten percent from every sale made on the opening night will be donated to the Australian Koala Foundation.
Supported by Kirin, Australian Koala Foundation and Big Chair Living.

item.title: Making Babies in the 21st Century - Fertility Preservation and Stem Cells
item.description:
From improving fertility options for women over 40 to assisting cancer patients with conception - the list of issues surrounding fertility are affecting increasing numbers of the Australian population.
The new opportunities raised by stem cell research and reproductive biology in the treatment of infertility will be the main focus of discussion as some of Australia's leading scientists come together at the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre on Sunday 24 August.
Hosted by the Society for Reproductive Biology (SRB), the 'Making babies in the 21st Century - Fertility Preservation and Stem Cells ' public forum will see internationally-renowned speakers examine what the science can offer now, and what the future holds.
The interactive forum moderated by Dr Rachel Nowak, internationally acclaimed science writer and knowledge broker, will see the public, healthcare professionals and community leaders come together to hear from scientists on the coalface of reproductive biology research.
This year's event will see one of the leading brains in stem cell research, Professor Alan Trounson of the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine (CIRM) address attendees at the forum.

item.title: Kissing the Blarney As It Flies
item.description:
Enjoy a heart-warming yarn about coming home, woven with songs, anecdotes and traditional stories.
Kissing the Blarney As It Flies is a tale of growing up in Australia, feeling like a foreigner, and making the journey to Ireland only to discover a homeland that is as familiar as it is foreign. Niki na Meadhra's journey loops around from Ireland back to Hobson's Bay where her Irish ancestors first arrived, when they settled in Victoria.
Niki is a professional storyteller and theatre artist, based at Abbotsford Convent, Melbourne. She has 25 years experience as a theatre maker, community builder and educator. Niki initially trained as an actor, but also has etensive experience directing and designing theatrical events. In 2012, she established her storytelling practice, Hearth Tales, which has already grown a significant audience in the community and education sectors. In 2012, Niki was invited to perform and lecture at Melbourne University. Her monthly event, Enchanted Evening, a night of traditional storytelling, sold out regularly in its first year. Niki uses stories to address social issues, reconnect audiences with traditional wisdom, nourish audiences in intimate community gatherings and to engender reflection, empathy and joy.

item.title: InfraHack – Melbourne Infrastructure Hack for Australia 3.0
item.description:
Join a two day hack challenge to tackle important problems like congestion and transport safety by re-imagining how we use our infrastructure. Infrastructure is a $40 trillion opportunity and maybe you'll spark the next disruption like Uber or Waze.
The Victorian Government and the City of Melbourne have provided rich data. NICTA (Australia's Information and Communications Research Centre of Excellence) is providing access to National Map which is loaded with great data after the recent Govhack. And more data is coming.
The challenge team are calling for creative minds to help us improve how transport and infrastructure works - it could be alleviating congestion, improving tram safety, fixing last mile freight in the city, apps to help citizens easily use the government data already available, or even letting us know what should be collected and what isn't being collected.
The challenge is open to all, and both developers and problem owners are encouraged to apply. Prizes include return tickets for two to Silicon Valley, passes to StartupGrind, memberships to Startup Victoria and open tickets to Australia's most progressive digital festival, Pause.
See the website for full details.

item.title: Docklands History Group
item.description:
Travel back in time with local historians, collectors, guest speakers and meet like-minded people at the monthly Docklands History Group.
Share a cuppa and stories with other local history enthusiasts and learn about the people, places and industries from times gone by.
This month join Jenny Bygrave, Kate O'Neill and John Riley from the Port of Melbourne Corporation and learn about the presence of the port in the Docklands area and the history of Melbourne's port development over time.
Held on the fourth Thursday of the month and everyone is welcome.

item.title: David Whiting – Estate Planning
item.description:
Hear expert David Whiting speak on issues of estate planning - the power and the pitfalls - and then take part in a Q&A session.
David works in many areas of the law, and so is able to act as well-informed counselor to his clients, providing advice and assistance on big decisions and stressful problems. The favorite compliment of his career? 'You gave me real peace of mind'. He describes himself as focusing on clients' deals, disputes and desires.
In the area of wills and probate, he prepares wills and powers of attorney and assists in their administration. Where necessary he makes or defends claims against them. On request, he will act as executor. He has a number of clients where he acts as their attorney, and will later act as their executor.
A born generalist, he has diligently avoided specialisation. 'In an ever-changing world, narrowing your focus limits your opportunities, and your usefulness,' he says. He looks for the big picture, while under-standing the detail.
Tea and coffee available on arrival. Please be seated by 10.30am.

item.title: Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime at Southbank Melbourne
item.description:
Celebrate Book Week and National Reading Hour with a Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime. Wear your pajamas, bring a cuddly friend and listen to some great stories before heading home to bed.
'The Reading Hour initiative reminds parents and caregivers that reading together doesn’t have to be a massive undertaking in their busy lives, and that sharing a book with a child for 10 minutes a day – or just over an hour a week – will still give that child the best chance of becoming a good reader later in life, along with all the social and educational benefits it brings.' (Love2read.org.au 2014)

item.title: Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime at North Melbourne
item.description:
Celebrate Book Week and National Reading Hour with a Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime. Wear your pajamas, bring a cuddly friend and listen to some great stories before heading home to bed.
'The Reading Hour initiative reminds parents and caregivers that reading together doesn’t have to be a massive undertaking in their busy lives, and that sharing a book with a child for 10 minutes a day – or just over an hour a week – will still give that child the best chance of becoming a good reader later in life, along with all the social and educational benefits it brings.' (Love2read.org.au 2014)

item.title: Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime at Library at The Dock
item.description:
Celebrate Book Week and National Reading Hour with these Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytimes. Wear your pajamas, bring a cuddly friend and listen to some great stories before heading home to bed.
The Reading Hour initiative reminds parents and caregivers that reading together doesn't have to be a massive undertaking in their busy lives, and that sharing a book with a child for 10 minutes a day - or just over an hour a week - will still give that child the best chance of becoming a good reader later in life, along with all the social and educational benefits it brings.

item.title: Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytime at East Melbourne
item.description:
Celebrate Book Week and National Reading Hour with these Connect to Reading Bedtime Storytimes. Wear your pajamas, bring a cuddly friend and listen to some great stories before heading home to bed.
The Reading Hour initiative reminds parents and caregivers that reading together doesn't have to be a massive undertaking in their busy lives, and that sharing a book with a child for 10 minutes a day - or just over an hour a week - will still give that child the best chance of becoming a good reader later in life, along with all the social and educational benefits it brings.

item.title: Alone With Bees
item.description:
Alone with Bees is sweet music with a sting and the original project from jazz artist Connie Lansberg. Set in the friendly and intimate setting of Chaucer Cellars in Glen Iris, where the the wine, the food and music are all excellent. It's free to get in but bookings are essential.
An evening at this popular neighbourhood treasure is worth venturing out of your own neighbourhood for on a cold rainy night. Plenty of street parking.

item.title: Acoustica at City Library – Music Trivia with Jess McGuire
item.description:
This month, City Library brings you something a little different. Come and test your music trivia knowledge with Jess McGuire.
Test your general knowledge, music awareness and all-round fact nerdery. Prizes, fame and the chance to become a knowledge master await you.
Jess McGuire is a writer and broadcaster. She can be found regularly on 774 ABC Melbourne and weekly on 720 ABC Perth's Drive show. She was the editor of pop culture website Defamer Australia and has written for assorted publications including the Sydney Morning Herald, The Age, Meanjin, the Daily Life and the Sunday Age.

item.title: Acoustica – Read to Me Tuesday
item.description:
Come to the City Library for Read to Me Tuesday with musician Dave Evans and reader Steph Francis.
Steph Francis initiated Read to Me Tuesday with Dave Evans as a means to bring great fiction writing into a public space.
It's a very different experience to reading a short story alone. When stories are performed with music and voice, they acquire vivid new dimensions - and the focus of those listening creates an atmosphere that is quite magical.

item.title: Thessaloniki & Melbourne Sister City Festival
item.description:
Thessaloniki Association's Annual Festival in the centre of Melbourne celebrates the 30 year sister city relationship between the two cities.
The Thessaloniki Association's Annual Festival in the heart of Melbourne is presented in co-operation with the Hellenic Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (HACCI). Attendees of the festival include the Mayor of Thessaloniki Mr G. Boutaris, the Lord Mayor of Melbourne Mr R. Doyle, and several MPs from Victoria and Thessaloniki.
There'll be plenty of Greek food, a food exhibition, performances, business delegations and lots of fun. Cooks from Greece will demonstrate their cooking skills and offer Greek food tasting. Businesses from Greece and Melbourne will present their wares. Plus there will be stalls, performers, dancers and musicians to entertain the crowds.
Program starting at 1pm to be distributed on the day, speeches at 4pm.

item.title: Bound/Unbound
item.description:
Paper Arts Gippsland East's members are all interested in paper - its manufacture, use and inherent qualities that make it an extremely versatile media for artists working in a range of techniques - including many textile artists.
Altered books, changing the surface of the paper, layering, painting with pulp, artist books and boxes, alternative print transfer techniques, eco dying, making handmade paper with natural fibres, marbling, book binding and paper construction are just some of the practices and processes that members learn.
Bound/Unbound will include a range of works on paper demonstrating a variety of techniques, both 2D and 3D artworks as well as an assortment of handmade and commercial paper.

item.title: Horsham Car & Bike Show
item.description:
The Horsham Car and Bike Show will hold it's annual Show and Shine event in March Labour Day weekend.
Event organisers raise funds for the Wimmera Against Cancer in Kids group, which assists families who are having to deal with the trauma of having a child with cancer.
For more information, please see the website.

item.title: National Gemboree
item.description:
All roads leads to Horsham Victoria during the 2015 National Gemboree. The Horsham & District Lapidary Club will be hosting the 51st National Gem and Mineral Show at the Wimmera Events Centre during Easter 2015.
Come and see beautiful minerals like fluorite specimen on display along with a range of gems, fossils, jewellery, beads, meteorites, craft tools and equipment, there is sure to be something to bring a smile to anyone's face.
This amazing show will attract visitors from around Australia and overseas. Visitors will be able to browse or buy from a huge range of gems, minerals, jewellery, beads just to name a few.
View demonstrations of a wide range of lapidary and jewellery crafts, see the experts first hand demonstrating their amazing skills.
