It is with great pleasure that Horsham Rural City Council welcomes all exhibitors and visitors from far and wide to the 2015 Gemboree National Gem and Mineral Show.

item.title: Pamela Gordon Art Exhibition
item.description: This Exhibition at the Mont De Lancey Historic property in the Yarra Valley covers a diverse range of Pamela's work. She believes passionately that art enriches our lives. Mainly a pastel artist she also works with acrylics, oils and watercolour. She finds inspiration for her paintings in her local surroundings in the Yarra Valley and from holiday destinations. Pamela never travels without a sketch book. One of her favourite subjects is vineyards, where she has been allowed to paint on site. Pamela utilizes strong colour, crisp line to convey the mastery of her mediums. Open every day except Monday and Tuesday

item.title: Buninyong Good Life Festival
item.description:
The Buninyong Good Life Festival is a community focused annual celebration of ideas, interests and what it means to live The Good Life! It aims to promote awareness of DonateLife Victoria while encouraging and supporting other local causes.
With a focus on health, the 2014 festival will once again be organising The King Of The Mountain Fun Run/Walk as well as incorporating a Health Hub and other interactive activities.
The festival is a free family fun day full of entertainment, market stalls, children's precinct with pantomime performances and craft activities and much, much more - something for everyone!

item.title: Diversity in Print
item.description:
Presenting Diversity in Print at the new Station Gallery and Community Arts Hub, this exhibition is sure to be a fantastic show.
Come down and view prints by Gerard Dovey, Bob Hickman, Lisa Kurec, Jenny Peterson, Libby Schreiber and Helen Timbury.
For more information, please call the Station Gallery in Yarragon.

item.title: Kangan Institute Open Day - Moonee Ponds Campus
item.description:
Take the opportunity explore the Moonee Ponds Campus training facilities, learn more about the courses and workplace skills development programs offered, and meet the expert teaching team.
So come along between 10.00am and 4.00pm and find out why Kangan has a reputation for delivering training solutions that help people to reach their potential and organisations to grow.
With exhibits from some of the Kangan industry partners including Nissan Motorsport and the Mantra Tullamarine Hotel, practical demonstrations, live music, a fashion show and great prizes to be won on the day, the Open Day is not to be missed!

item.title: Kangan Institute Open Day - Richmond Campus
item.description:
Take the opportunity explore the Richmond Campus training facilities, learn more about the courses and workplace skills development programs offered, and meet the expert teaching team.
So come along between 4.30pm and 6.30pm and find out why Kangan has a reputation for delivering training solutions that help people to reach their potential and organisations to grow.
With exhibits from some of the Kangan industry partners including Nissan Motorsport and the Mantra Tullamarine Hotel, practical demonstrations, live music, a fashion show and great prizes to be won on the day, the Open Day is not to be missed!

item.title: Kangan Institute Open Day - Richmond Campus
item.description:
Take the opportunity explore the Richmond Campus training facilities, learn more about the courses and workplace skills development programs offered, and meet the expert teaching team.
So come along between 10.00am and 4.00pm and find out why Kangan has a reputation for delivering training solutions that help people to reach their potential and organisations to grow.
With exhibits from some of the Kangan industry partners including Nissan Motorsport and the Mantra Tullamarine Hotel, practical demonstrations, live music, a fashion show and great prizes to be won on the day, the Open Day is not to be missed!

item.title: Children's Week - Aussie Backyard Bird Count
item.description:
Monday 20 - Sunday 26 October 2014
The Aussie Backyard Bird Count is Australia's first nationwide bird survey! Join thousands of people as they get to know their local birds during BirdLife Australia's Bird Week (20-26 October 2014) and help us discover how our birds are faring.
All it takes it 15 minutes in your backyard, neighbourhood park or favourite green patch to be a part of this exciting citizen science event!

image.altText: Children's Week Aussie Backyard Bird Count
Children's Week Aussie Backyard Bird Count

item.title: Capture Winter at Queenscliff Harbour
item.description:
Winter isn't a time to stay indoors and wait for Spring - it might be the time to rug up but honestly when the sun is shining on Queenscliff Harbour without a breath of wind you wouldn't want to be anywhere else regardless of the time of year.
You are inviting you to Capture Winter at Queenscliff Harbour, so no matter if you are just in the right place at the right time with a mobile phone or plan to visit us with the latest & greatest SLR your photo could win you prizes to cheer away the winter blues.
Here is your chance to be a winner in the "Capture" Winter at Queenscliff Harbour photo competition with $500 cash going to the person that takes the best photo plus vouchers valued at $250 / $150 for the runner up & 3rd prize.
Queenscliff Harbour are also offering separately $300 to the school of the best "student" photo.
See website for full program details.

item.title: Still Life with Fruit, Sculpture Unveiling, Vegetable Talk and Guided Art walk
item.description:
The sculpture to be unveiled, Still Life with Fruit by Lachlan Plain will be a painterly rendition of the food gardener's fruit bowl.
At ten times the fruit's original size this fibre glass sculpture will tower over the entrance of Bulleen Art & Garden, testament to BAAG's commitment to food gardening.
After being inspired to grow your own produce get some practical advice on how to get started and keep committed with a talk about fruit trees and vegetable gardens.
There will also be guided walks will explore the artworks across the site.

image.altText: Still Life with Fruit, Sculpture Unveiling, Vegetable Talk and Guided Art walk
Still Life with Fruit, Sculpture Unveiling, Vegetable Talk and Guided Art walk

item.title: Feathers, Fur and Fins
item.description:
Feathers, Fur and Fins is an exhibition of ceramic (and some copper) sculpture by Yow Yow Studio at the Bolin Bolin Gallery at Bulleen Art & Garden.
The Yow Yow Girls, Sharon, Andrea and Sue, have worked together in clay, for more than 10 years and 5 years ago established the Studio at St Andrews, the name came about because the Yow Yow Creek joins the Diamond Creek, on the property.
The common thread with these three artists is their love for a Clay called B.R.T, it is chunky, strong, forgiving and you seem to be able to make almost anything with it. Their collective Art practice has evolved to incorporate collaborative pieces such as the Totems, with an endless variety of combinations of "Feathers Fins & Fur" for you to create your own individual Garden Sculpture.

ns0:venue.name: Bolin Bolin Gallery at Bulleen Art & Garden

item.title: The Mission Foods Mexican Festival
item.description:
This year's Mission Foods Mexican Festival will have your Sunday fun wrapped up like a soft shell taco when Federation Square becomes a mini Mexico on Sunday September 14.
All the essential ingredients are there for a colourful day full of flavours, sounds and experiences for the third annual Mission Foods Mexican Festival, which coincides each year with Mexican Independence Day.
Featuring arts and crafts, authentic cuisine, live music and much much more!
Last year, the Festival attracted over 30,000 people to Federation Square and this year, the free event is expected to be even bigger, brighter and more delicious.

address.address1: Corner Swanston St and Flinders St

item.title: Soul Food
item.description:
Soul Food is a unique monthly event held at the State Library of Victoria. It provides an opportunity to unite in a tranquil environment and reflect on inspiring themes and common threads that tie us all together.
This relaxed gathering features live music, audio-visual pieces and readings from faiths and philosophers, authors, leaders and indigenous cultures from all over the world.
The purpose of Soul Food is to inspire us to transform peoples lives, peoples neighbourhoods and communities, with actions that promote the unity and betterment of society.
Soul Food is a free community event open to all.

item.title: Skins - Jan Herrera, Anne Galbraith and Vicky Barker
item.description:
This month the Gallery at City Library features Skins and an exhibition showing works from Jan Herrera, Anne Galbraith and Vicky Barker.
Skins is a show which explores the interface between the body and the outside world, looking at the skins we show the world, the skins we sometimes hide behind, shown here through scuplture, encaustic wax, painting and large-scale illustrations from three woman artists showing for the first time together.
Anne Galbraith has studied art for four years in the Diploma of Visual Arts through the CAE, focusing on sculpture and painting.
A practising artist for 10 years, Jan Herrera completed a Diploma of Visual Art at NMIT with a major in printmaking and painting. She is currently undertaking her second Diploma of Visual Art, majoring in sculpture.
Vicki Barker is a Melbourne-based artist currently studying visual arts at Box Hill Institute, CAE. Her work explores the many facets of hair - from its structure to how we love or loathe it. Being a visual artist, she uses drawing, painting, sculpture and hair to create a variety of works.

item.title: Castrol Edge CIK Stars of Karting Championship
item.description:
Round Five of Australia's elite karting championship, the Castrol Edge CIK Stars of Karting Championship, takes place in Port Melbourne.
Competitors in three internationally recognised classes - KZ2, KF2 and KF3 - will reach speeds in excess of 120km/h around the Todd Road circuit.
Former champions of the CIK Stars of Karting Championship include Formula One driver Daniel Ricciardo, V8 Supercar Champion Jamie Whincup and Bathurst 1000 Champion Mark Winterbottom, along with V8 supercar drivers Michael Caruso and Tim Slade.
More than 150 drivers will be competing at the event, ranging from competitors in the Rookies class, where drivers are aged between 9 and 12 years old, through to TAG 125 classes and the three feature CIK classes.

item.title: Basil Sellers Art Prize – Family Artivity
item.description:
The Basil Sellers Art Prize brings together Melbourne's dual loves of art and sport. Dive into the exhibition with a curated tour and arty activity designed to entertain and engage the whole family.
The Ian Potter Museum of Art, The University of Melbourne, has joined forces with Culture Mamas to present a series of family-friendly workshops for the Basil Sellers Art Prize exhibition.
The Basil Sellers Family Art-ivities offer parents and children a chance to learn, explore and play together. Each session includes an introduction to the exhibition, a discovery trail of selected works and a chance to make your own artwork.
The workshops are the perfect way to introduce young minds to art and are specifically designed to entertain and engage little ones while also presenting information and inspiration for adults.
The workshops incorporate activities to engage toddlers, pre-schoolers and early primary school age children.

ns0:venue.name: The Ian Potter Museum of Art

item.title: Alex Miller: The Story's Not Over Yet
item.description:
The 2nd Australian Literature ASAL Patrons Lecture 2014 features a talk and conversation by award-winning Australian novelist Alex Miller.
Speaking on place, story and Australian writing in this special session at the Library at the Dock, Miller will trace the trajectory of his own writing career. His lecture will look at the nature of literature, history and the state of contemporary Australian literature, particularly the exciting developments in Indigenous writing in Australia.
The talk will be followed by a brief conversation and question and answer session with Alex Miller conducted by Sydney University Professor of Australian Literature, Robert Dixon.

item.title: 2014 Brookes Oration
item.description:
The annual Brookes Oration honours the significant contribution of Sir Wilfred Brookes, grandson of Alfred Deakin, the second Prime Minister of Australia, after whom Deakin University is named. The Oration is a free event open to all the public.
The Brookes Oration was established by the Deakin Graduate School of Business in 2006 to encourage thoughtful debate about the contribution of corporate Australia in the global community.
This year's oration, The Importance of Ethics - Making Business Good Business, will be delivered by Ms Ita Buttrose, AO OBE, legendary media editor, businesswoman, best-selling author, committed community and welfare contributor and 2013 Australian of the Year.

item.title: Horsham Triathlon
item.description:
The 2015 Horsham Triathlon will be held on Saturday 14th February, with the junior "Come and Try" event held first followed by the senior event. Mark the date in your calendar now!!
The event will once again be part of the Telstra Store Rural Tri Series, covering five rural triathlons to be held at Benalla, Echuca-Moama, Albury-Wodonga, Horsham and Shepparton.
More details later in 2014

item.title: 2014 Yarra Sustainability Awards
item.description:
Join us along with our host and MC, stand-up comedian, actor, writer and radio personality, Dave O'Neil and the winners of the Yarra Sustainability Awards for a community celebration of innovative and inspirational achievements in sustainability in Yarra.
The program features guest speaker 2013 'Local Hero' Nick Buckley, an opportunities to network and connect with local groups, businesses, community organisations, schools, architects and designers committed to environmental sustainability, live entertainment, drinks and canapés, digital stories from winning and commended nominees.
This is a free and accessible event and all are welcome to attend. Event times are 6:00pm - 9:00pm (Registrations open at 5:45pm)
RSVP to Access Yarra: (03) 9205 5555 info@yarracity.vic.gov.au by Friday, 5 September 2014.
If you have particular access or interpreting requirements please contact 9205 5769 prior to Friday, 29 August 2014.

item.title: Resume Techniques - Essentials to Secure Job Interviews
item.description:
NotedCareers proudly presents the fifth seminar of Career Management Seminar Series titled Resume Techniques - Essentials To Secure Job Interviews
This seminar will address following topics:
- Basic approaches to design your effective resume - Fallacies in resume writing - The latest developments in resume writing
Discuss your career situation with our consultants at the conclusion of the event!
Plus, a chance to register for a free private resumes check session!

item.title: Peter O'Doherty - From the Street
item.description:
Peter O'Doherty will be holding his first Melbourne show in almost a decade at Gould Galleries.
Peter O'Doherty's first artistic incarnation emerged in the popular band Mental as Anything. Unlike his brother Reg Mombassa and the other members O'Doherty did not attend art school - in 2000 he left the band to focus on his highly successful full-time art career.
The early influence of watching his carpenter father construct houses led O'Doherty to develop an acute awareness of the built environment, which has become the primary subject matter for his paintings.

item.title: Hamilton Quilters: Two Colour Harmony
item.description:
There has been a renewed interest in craft and needlework in recent years as traditional arts and crafts enjoy a revival with a younger generation.
Quilts in particular are familiar objects, yet every stitch has the power to carry a range of stories and histories. These works can often hold immense family value, lovingly handed down through the generations.
The Hamilton Quilters have been delighting Western Victoria with their dedication, skill and creativity with this popular medium for over 30 years. This exhibition will mark the group's 16th biennial exhibition in the gallery with a variety of techniques and ideas on display themed around 'Two Colour Harmony'.

item.title: William Hogarth: Characters and Caricatures
item.description:
William Hogarth was most famously known for his biting commentary on 18th century manners and morals. A controversial and individualistic character he was driven by a sense for justice and missed no chance to assert his opinion even if he meant he got into a quarrel with his contemporaries.
This selection of prints from the Gallery's holdings looks at his satire and preoccupation with caricature in his work.
The term caricature is defined as a 'grotesque representation of a person by the exaggeration of the characteristic traits in picture, writing or mime'. We will not offer the writing or the mime but the exhibition will consist of some entertaining pictures!

item.title: Hamilton Tops 2014
item.description:
Now in its twelfth year, Hamilton Tops 2014 features work created by local VCE students undertaking studies in Studio Arts and Visual Communication and Design.
The exhibition highlights Hamilton Art Gallery's strong commitment and support of arts education in the region and celebrates the talents and achievements of the local youth. Audiences are provided with an insight into the ideas and influences that inspire arts students.
Work is selected from secondary schools in the Shire: Baimbridge College, Hamilton and Alexandra College, Monivae College, Good Shepherd College and Balmoral Community College.

item.title: Illumination: The art of Philip Wolfhagen
item.description:
This exhibition Illumination: The art of Philip Wolfhagen is the first major survey of this Tasmanian artist.
A landscape artist, Wolfhagen is a master of creating works of art that capture changing light and mood, temperature and atmosphere. To view his paintings is to be seduced by the fleeting elements of weather and the ever-changing qualities of nature. It is this ethereal quality that makes his art so appealing to collectors and art galleries both in Australia and overseas.
The exhibition will travel to 6 other venues across four states and the ACT.

image.altText: ILLUMINATION: The art of Philip Wolfhagen
ILLUMINATION: The art of Philip Wolfhagen

item.title: Transcendence: Photographs by David Stephenson
item.description:
David Stephenson has photographed a range of subjects in countries around the world, including landscapes, skyscapes, cityscapes and cathedral ceilings.
Stephenson uses photography to explore abstract, intangible themes including time, mortality and spirituality. While the immediate subject of his works has varied, the underlying themes and ideas within his photographs have remained consistent.

item.title: Prints: Recent Gifts and Acquisitions
item.description:
The Hamilton Art Gallery holds over 1500 prints spanning from the 17th century onwards. They frequently come into the collection as the result of gifts and many of the prints in this exhibition have arrived as a consequence of this. Others we purchase in an attempt to maintain the breadth of the collection or to represent emerging media. They are usually of Australian origin these days and so this exhibition draws together some of the recent Australian prints we have added to the collection.
Artists represented include Noel Counihan, Ron Quick, Paul Baxter, Dean Bowen, Brent Harris and local artist Danny McDonald.

item.title: The Fabulous Shaw Bequest: Revisited
item.description:
General consensus was that the superb showing of a selection of works from the Shaw Bequest organised in 2013 was on for too short a time so we are revisiting one of the greatest gifts received by the arts in Australia's history and the core of the Hamilton collection.
For more information, please see website.

item.title: Wayne Viney: Singular Impressions
item.description:
Singular Impressions surveys Melbourne artist, Wayne Viney's responses to landscape over the past thirty years. Best known for his hauntingly evocative twilight studies, Viney masterfully draws upon the painterly potential of monotypes in his exploration of the pastoral tradition.
This exhibition maps his transition from gestural drawings grounded in physical sites such as the Strathbogie Ranges and Yea, to his signature brooding monotypes of psychic landscapes, to recent colourband abstractions. Whether depicting the observed countryside of the Australian bush, or giving expression to the private vistas of an imagined scene, Viney imbues his images with a mood that is achingly sublime.

item.title: Mont De Lancey Annual Art Exhibition
item.description:
The Mont De Lancey Annual Art Exhibition showcases and encourages talented local artists from the Yarra Valley.
It is held within the beautiful grounds of the historic homestead of Mont De Lancey in the Ray Oliver Gallery.
The exhibition will include a diverse range of content and media. You may find a work from the exhibition that would look beautiful in your home.

image.altText: Mont De Lancey Annual Art Exhibition
Mont De Lancey Annual Art Exhibition

item.title: Brett Jarrett Wildlife Art Exhibition
item.description:
Wildlife artist Brett Jarrett will be exhibiting more than forty wildlife paintings at this year's Kyneton Daffodil & Arts Festival. Brett has dedicated his entire life to observing and documenting the behaviour and identification of wildlife, in particular marine birds and mammals.
This is a unique opportunity to see one of the country's leading nature painters and enjoy the realism and anatomy that are at the forefront of his artistic passion, creating subjects that are both authentic and believable. The past three years his work has been accepted by the prestigious Society of Animal Artists for their annual exhibition and national tour in the U.S.A.
A professional artist of twenty three years including work as a guide and field biologist, he has become the most travelled and experienced of Australia's modern day animal painters while exploring all of Antarctica's coastline; sailing the entire eastern tropical Pacific and twice reaching the geographic North Pole all in search of rare and exotic wildlife.
Brett has just returned from sailing to the North Pole onboard the world's most powerful nuclear ice-breaker as a special guest entertaining passengers with his artwork along with painting demonstrations.
All paintings exhibited at the historic Mechanics Institute are oil on canvas and cover a huge variety of wildlife such as whales, dolphins, penguins, albatross, pelicans, swans, zebras, polar bears, koalas and wrens.
During the exhibition Brett will be available to answer any questions about realism painting as well as demonstrating his technique. Exhibition open 10.00am - 4.00pm from the 5th - 7th September, 12th - 14th September in the Mechanics Institute, 81 Mollison Street, Kyneton. For further information on Brett's exhibition telephone 0415 464 572.

item.title: Nanneella Community Clearing Sale & Auction
item.description:
Turn your Spring Clean into cash! Time to clean out those cupboards and sheds and you may be surprised by how much these unwanted items are worth!
If you are a collector or bargain hunter then Nanneella is the place for you! With a whole reserve of sale items to choose from you might just find what you didn't know you had been looking for!
Enjoy catching up with friends and neighbours in friendly, country atmosphere.

item.title: Birregurra Festival and Art Show
item.description: The 15th annual Birregurra Festival and Art Show is set to transform the streets of Birregurra into a vibrant market place, rich with a diverse range of live music, art, Otway region produce, gourmet food, plants and handcrafts. There is plenty for the children, a popular dog jumping contest, and a successful art show, featuring work from leading Victorian artists. Entry is by gold coin donation.

item.title: Revealed
item.description: Art at Linden Gate presents Revealed by Studio 4 Artists Inc. This exhibition is the result of regular life drawing sessions . The diverse styles and takes on nudes make for an interesting display. Admire the beauty of the human form while also enjoying the stunning views of the Yarra Valley.

item.title: The Art of Botanical Illustration
item.description:
The Friends of the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne present the Twelfth Art of Botanical Illustration Exhibition, featuring over 150 works of Botanic Art by leading artists from Australia and overseas.
All works of art will be for sale. Funds raised will go towards projects within the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.
Please note Sunday 9 November hours 10am to 4pm

item.title: Mindfulness & Meditation seminar
item.description:
The aim of this free seminar is to introduce mindfulness-meditation to people who want to learn about the practical benefits it offers for stress management, well-being and general health - both physical and mental.
The seminar will discuss the origins of mindfulness meditation and how it is used by millions of people around the world to increase concentration, awareness and improve performance.
Always Meditation offers meditation courses and mindfulness workshops around Melbourne. They offer practical knowledge and are non-religious or dogmatic. This free seminar is an introduction to the material they teach during their paid courses.

item.title: Market of the Mind
item.description:
Explore the science of cocktails, laugh yourself silly with science comedy, dance to the beat of your heart and discover the true facts about the lemur and other mis–represented creatures.
Market of the Mind is where the cerebral, the scientific and the social collide. Experience live music, speed-meet a scientist and see inside-out people at a truly unique event.
This 'City Science' event is presented by National Science Week.

item.title: Craft Cubed Festival
item.description:
Craft is presenting a program of over 120 events spread across Melbourne and regional Victoria. The festival features exhibitions, public installations, open studios, markets, online events, films, talks and seminars.
There will be unrivalled access to craft makers and educators and opportunities to learn new skills, master techniques, collaborate on public works, make new friends and celebrate the amazing creativity and diversity of craft culture.
Highlights include Big Ceramics at Fed Square, curated by Craft CEO and Artistic Director Jane Scott, which features some of Australia's most celebrated ceramic artists as well as exhibitions onsite, three with a jewellery focus: Transplantation (local/international jewellery ), Vito Bila (Melbourne) and Bin Dixon Ward (Melbourne). Textile designer and illustrator, Sandra Eterovic will also be featured in the Craft Window.
Free activities presented by Craft feature creative and cultural groups, artists, makers, sector professionals and educators in a dynamic and engaging program that covers everything from Lost Trades to Craftivism.
The Festival also features the highly anticipated Craft Hatch market - an incubator event for emerging creatives - as well as a seminar that will provide unique insights for anyone considering starting, or already involved in, the craft and design sector. The seminar features leading craft makers, designers and industry professionals who have successfully managed to make the most of their creative talent.
Please see website for full program of events.

item.title: Naturally Loddon - Photographic Nature
item.description:
Join with Friends of Kooyoora members in taking photos of the wonders of Kooyoora State Park. Learn how to use the buttons on your camera and the best techniques.
You don't have to have a flash machine to take good photos. We have some wonderful photographers in our group who don't always see things the way others do.
Meet at 10.30am at the Melville Caves Picnic ground. BYO lunch.
For further details visit our website.

item.title: Duplicate - Finding a Home: An Information session from Home at Last and Consumer Affairs Victoria
item.description:
Older Persons' Housing Information and Support Service. Join Consumer Affairs Victoria for a free discussion on affordable housing options for seniors presented by Home at Last and Consumer Affairs Victoria. Plus your rights and responsibilities in retirement housing and private rental, as well as how to avoid scams- presented by Consumer Affairs Victoria
August 7th 10am-12pm Mornington Peninsula Shire, Hastings Office, Reception Meeting Room 3, 21 Marine Pde, Hastings
August 21st 10am-12pm Mornington Peninsula Shire, Mornington Office, Library Meeting Room, Queen Street, Mornington
August 28th 10am-12pm Mornington Peninsula Shire, Rosebud Office, Meeting Room 3, Besgrove Street, Rosebud
Light Lunch Provided. Bookings Phone 9654 7389

image.altText: Finding a Home: An Information session from Home at Last and Consumer Affairs Victoria
Finding a Home: An Information session from Home at Last and Consumer Affairs Victoria

item.ns0:organiser: Housing for the Aged Action Group

item.title: The Designer Craft Market at Buninyong
item.description:
The Designer Craft Market at Buninyong is an exciting Market offering high-quality handcrafted items for sale to the community by talented local and regional designers and artists.
Held in the beautiful Historic Buninyong Town Hall, you are sure to find something delightful, full of that handmade goodness, bringing a family friendly shopping experience to lovers of beautifully unique treats and gifts.

item.title: Illuminated Memories
item.description:
Illuminated Memories, an exhibition by Nikki D'Emden
Artist talk: Saturday 16 August, 2pm (Free)
After a nearly sell-out exhibition at "69 Smith Street" 2014, Nikki D'Emden is now sharing her sumptuous new works in Illuminated Memories.
Her mixed media pieces are inspired by found objects and her interest in Asian art and artefacts.
Her practice involves predominantly the use of oil glazes over gold and silver leaf on wooden panels as well as mixed media works that combine oils paint and glazes, gold leaf, intaglio prints and found materials on canvas.
In a number of her works the transparency and ethereal quality of oil glazes layered over gold leaf comment on the fragility of our natural environment.
These are more than golden memories, they have a depth built of the actual material and allude to a poignant message about climatic effects and seasonal changes.

item.title: March In August
item.description:
Mark the one year anniversary of the Abbott Government by joining a nationwide citizens' march to demand accountability, transparency, and decency from the Federal Government.
This is a non-partisan people's 'vote of no confidence' in government policies that are against the common good; and that violate the principles of humanity, decency, fairness, social justice and equity, democratic governance, responsible global citizenship and conserving our natural heritage.
Many Australians are deeply concerned with the way our country is being governed. They are concerned over issues that directly affect them, their families, and indeed all Australians. They are concerned about the policies and behaviour of Australian political parties. They are concerned with the direction in which Australia's great civil society is heading.
People must raise our voices. We all want what's best for Australia; let's tell our elected representatives directly how we want that to happen.
Display your demands on placards (with clean language) and imagination, dress up, make lots of noise, and let's show the government that we, their employers, are watching and are united to demand better.
March Australia. Australians united for better government.

item.title: Carols By Candlelight in Horsham
item.description:
Carols By Candlelight in Horsham is an entertaining family evening out as you sing along a to Christmas Carols with the choir.
There will be food stalls available and entertainment for the children prior to the commencement of the carols.
Bring along a chair or picnic blanket and picnic basket enjoy the community spirit. Candles and programs available for a gold coin donation.

item.title: Makers Gallery Christmas Market
item.description:
The Maker's Gallery holds their annual Christmas Market, where you will find many local art and craft products and items to purchase, Great for those hard to buy for relatives and friends. It might even inspire you to get into that craft item you have been putting off.
Held once a year in front of the Horsham Library, this market as so much to offer and is not to be missed.

item.title: Natimuk Farmers Market Plus
item.description:
Natimuk is nestled at the base of Mt Arapiles and Mitre Rock; a peoples Market comprising of three distinct sections, the Natimuk Farmers Market Plus has something for everyone.
The Sunday market is a central place where people gather to support local and regional produce growers including organic producers, local artists and craft persons in a vibrant lively music atmosphere. Community groups provide sausage sizzle, sweet and savory crepes include gluten free and vegan, plus tea and coffee.

item.title: Haven Market
item.description:
All are welcome to the Haven Market, a monthly event held on the first Saturday of each month from 9am to 1pm (with the exception of January) Convened by the Haven Recreation Reserve committee, all funds raised are used to improve facilities for the benefit of the community, the local primary school and visitors.
Hundreds of people enjoy the relaxed atmosphere of the Market located in a picturesque bush setting only five minutes from the city centre of Horsham.
There is always a diverse range of stalls from delicious homemade sauces, relish, cakes and jams, locally grown honey, organic vegetables, bread and buns, through to locally made arts and crafts, baby produce, plants and many others.
Sit and enjoy a cappuccino or hot chocolate, or indulge in a hot jam donut while listening to the live music provided by Don Papst and his members of the Key Change band.
The Market is renowned for its Egg & Bacon Muffin Breakfast supplied by the local tennis club, followed by a barbecue supplied by the local primary school.
Please don't miss Haven's monthly market - it is a very popular event - not just for the produce it provides but also the welcoming community spirit of the bush.

item.title: Oakridge Wines: Yarra Valley Open Studios
item.description:
Make sure you see the group exhibition at Oakridge Winery, showcasing work from each artist - a great way to start your Open Studios journey.
Book in for an 'Open Studios' inspired breakfast at Oakridge Winery from 8am on the weekend of the event.
Yarra Valley Open Studios is a unique trifecta of food, wine and art. The 'Valley' is already well renowned for its great producers of quality food and wine. Including art into the mix, completes the picture.
Beautiful rolling hills and vineyards are a stunning backdrop to this incredibly personal and inspiring art experience. Participating artists allow us to catch a glimpse into their world and access the spaces in which they create and practise their craft.
What better way to start your day than with a coffee or an Open Studios inspired breakfast at Oakridge, surrounded by the Group Exhibition. This is a great way to plan your trip and set yourself up nicely for a wonderful day of creative discovery. And, as you meander through the Valley, you'll have the privilege of meeting some amazing people along the way.

item.title: The People's Weather Report
item.description:
Now more than ever, climate change is one of the most pressing issues facing our planet. It is easy to feel overwhelmed by the sheer magnitude and concerned by the polarising conversation. The People's Weather Report is a global response to the enormity of climate change from a very personal perspective: yours!
The People's Weather Report is seeking to recruit 300 'weather reporters' from around the world. These audio weather reports will be edited together and embedded as part of a sculptural sound installation created by eco designer Tanja Beer, and showcased during the sustainability festival Going Nowhere. Partner ABC RN will also be producing two one-hour packages for radio broadcast.
If you'd like to make a contribution and respond personally, politically, poetically or scientifically, reflecting on your individual connection to weather and the climate, email for full technical instructions on how to create your three- to five-minute audio weather report. Weather report submissions close on 13 October.
To learn more about Going Nowhere and the People's Weather Report, visit the website.

item.title: The Museum of Abject Sentimentality
item.description:
The Museum of Abject Sentimentality examines how contemporary artists use the abject object to explore historical notions of the sublime.
This The Museum of Abject Sentimentality investigates the implications of Freidrich Schillers' essay 'On Naïve and Sentimental Poetry' (1795 -1796), in which the author contemplates the interrelation of art, literature and abjection.

item.title: The Bloke Show
item.description:
The Bloke Show brings together seven artists who explore masculinity from different perspectives, whether critiquing white male colonisation of indigenous cultures, celebrating sporting heroes, or contemplating rural male isolation.
The exhibition forms the culmination of the 2014 RMIT Print Imaging Practice Residency. Artists have been commissioned to develop a print edition, which will be available for purchase from the galleries.

item.title: Streetworks
item.description:
Streetworks explores ways that art connect with audiences in real life situations and how spontaneous interactions on the street can animate public trust and facilitate exchange.
Burke's performative artworks on the street and in the marketplace use humour and street vendor-style strategies to engage directly with audiences.
Please see website for more information.

item.title: Spirituality and Psychology – What Makes Life Worth Living?
item.description:
Professor Miller (Columbia University, New York) is a world expert in the connection between spirituality and psychology. In this free seminar Professor Miller will answer several important questions. What does it mean to experience spiritual awakening? What can spiritually do about our feelings of emptiness, loneliness, and isolation? What can we do if our physical hunger is symptomatic of a greater spiritual hunger? What does it take to create a life plan full of energy, hope, and direction?
Professor Miller has worked for over two decades to integrate spirituality into mainstream research on mental health and wellness, publishing over 75 empirical peer review articles on spirituality and mental health in leading medical and psychology journals, including the American Journal of Psychiatry and Journal of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. Her work focuses on the spiritual awareness of children, adolescents and mothers, and benefits to mental health and wellness of spiritual awareness.
She is the editor of the critically acclaimed The Oxford Handbook of Psychology and Spirituality, a fascinating study in the intersection of religion, science, and psychology. The book includes contributions from eminent scholars in psychology, medicine, and physical and biological sciences from around the world. It forms part of the Oxford Library of Psychology
This is a rare chance for Melbournians to experience one of the world's preeminent minds, exploring spirituality and mental health.

item.title: Limitless City Artist Talk
item.description:
Limitless city: abstraction, materiality and authenticity is a single, focused project within the KINGS ARI 2014 program, achieved through four parts with four curated exhibitions that inform one other, and running sequentially from July to September.
The project will examine two key concepts of contemporaneity: the re-emergence of abstraction within contemporary art practice in Melbourne, and the emergence of and fascination with the nature of 21st Century reality.
Art Conversation: As part of Abstraction, Materiality and Authenticity Kings Artist Run will be hosting after work drinks and dialogue on the last Thursday of each of the curated exhibitions in this series.

item.title: Limitless City – Abstraction, Materiality and Authenticity
item.description:
Limitless City: Abstraction, Materiality and Authenticity is a single, focused project within the Kings Art 2014 program, with four curated exhibitions that inform one another, and running sequentially from July to September.
The project will examine two key concepts of contemporaneity: the re-emergence of abstraction within contemporary art practice in Melbourne, and the emergence of, and fascination with, the nature of 21st Century reality.
27 Jun-19 Jul - Of turning and syncing: Sophie Neate - Ribbon 1&2: Marcia Jane Curated by Matthew Berka and Diego Ramirez.
1 Aug–23 Aug - Connection to the Photosonicneurokineasthography: Botborg (Austria/Australia) Curated by Matthew Berka and Diego Ramirez.
- Differ: Charles O’Loughlin, Evan Morgan Grahame, Lucina Lane, Mia Kenway, Nick Ryrie, Renee Cosgrave, Taree MacKenzie, Fiona Morgan. Curated by Fiona Morgan.
29 Aug–20 Sept - The Art Fair Murders: Peter Hill (Superfiction)
26 Sept–18 Oct As If: The Institute of Critical Zoologists (SING), Jaquiline Drinkall (AUS), Patrick Pound (AUS/NZ), Michael Vale (AUS), Alexa Wright (UK), Seymour likely (NETHERLANDS), Joan Fontcuberta (SPAIN), Peter Hill (AUS/UK). Curated by Peter Hill and Siuli Tan.
As part of Abstraction, Materiality and Authenticity, Kings Artist Run will be hosting after-work drinks and dialogue at 6pm on the last Thursday of each of the curated exhibitions in this series: Thurs 17 July Thurs 21 August Thurs 18 Sept Thurs 16 Oct

item.title: Ines Hochgerner
item.description:
In this exhibition at RMIT Project Spce, Hochgerner's works put the relationship between human beings and common technological devices under surveillance as a means of carefully considering the definitions and notions of subject(ivity) and object(ivity).
Hochgerner is the recipient of the 2014 RMIT iAIR and AIR Krems residency exchange between Austria and Australia.

item.title: Faux Novel
item.description:
Faux Novel celebrates the shift between the material and the immaterial in contemporary art.
By focusing on signs in images, Hill and Lacroix play on objectivity and explore text and fictional storytelling as an art and exhibition making strategy.
See website for more information on floor talk and opening evening event.

item.title: Body Talk
item.description:
Body Talk is a dance video that parodies the TV variety show styles of the 1970s and '80s, using the idiom of the classic music program, Solid Gold.
The artist engages three dancers to investigate how feelings of remoteness and intimacy can be encouraged and enacted through choreography, media and performance, with particular focus on how the performers pathos appeals to the viewers' desire to be seduced.
Nick Chilvers' artworks draw directly from music, film and television, and investigate the participatory nature of pop, as it overlaps with the social rituals of contemporary performance art.

item.title: Azimuth
item.description:
Azimuth makes reference to the 'points of view' from which people view, experience and create in the world.
This exhibition is an exploration of the trajectories of practices borne out of ceramics, and gold and silver smithing traditions and brings together a group of contemporary object makers.
See website for more information.

item.title: Annual and Awards Exhibition
item.description:
Come to the ASV Annual and Awards Exhibition, a showcase of works by a group of sculptors, from aspiring to professional, who share a passion for expressing their ideas in bronze, ceramic, glass, steel, wire, wood and stone. It is the climax of the exhibiting year for the members and the culmination of a year's work.
As well as exhibiting their work, the artists are acknowledged and encouraged with various awards. A panel of judges award the prizes for emerging sculptors' work whilst peers judge more experienced members' work and visitors to the exhibition are invited to vote for the People's Choice Award. All works are selected by a panel and most are for sale. The exhibition will be officially opened, and prizes awarded, by Dr. J Patrick Greene OBE, CEO Museums Victoria, on 29th August, so come along for big night or browse the works and talk to the artists during business hours.

item.title: Healthy Harvest Festival
item.description:
Sarah Court Preschool will host its first Healthy Harvest Festival. A community-wide event, the Healthy Harvest Festival aims to inspire all people to buy locally, grow their own edible food and learn ways to prepare fresh, healthy meals.
The Festival is shaping up to be a great day of family fun, with live music, live horticulture and cooking demonstrations, loads of children's activities and market and community stalls. Their overarching goal is to bring residents together to celebrate their gardens and they hope to have a community-wide presence on the day.
Time: 9:00am - 1:00pm,
You can find out more on their website.

item.title: Luke Roberts - Kunstkamera an overview
item.description:
In August the curtain lifts on the much-anticipated Luke Roberts exhibition Kunstkamera at Anna Pappas Gallery. The exhibition will include painting, photography, video, sculpture and found objects providing a broad overview of the career of this icon of Australian art.
Major works from the AlphaStation/Alphaville series shown at the Institute of Modern Art, Brisbane (2010) and the Australian Centre for Photography, Sydney (2011) will be on display as well as works from Roberts' AMOROMA project resulting from his 2012 residency at the renowned British School at Rome.
Of course, no exhibition of Roberts' work would be complete without highlighting his strong history of performance. Over four decades Roberts has developed a world of elaborate mythology and multiple personas. Images of and items belonging to his most famous persona, Pope Alice, as well as some of Roberts other notable personas will be featured in the exhibition. This year marks a significant milestone for Roberts' celebrated persona Alice Jitterbug, who first visited the National Gallery of Victoria forty years ago in 1974. This timely overview will also contain a live performance element, an unorthodox occurrence within the commercial gallery setting yet one integral to the artist's oeuvre and especially relevant for this historic anniversary.

item.title: Hearing Awareness Week
item.description: Concerned about your hearing needs? Not happy about the hearing services that you are currently receiving? Eaglehawk Hearing Clinic is offering free hearing checks; free discussion of your current hearing aids and even free hearing aid trials to experience the latest technology for suitable candidates. Visit the Clinic any time during the week between 9.00am to 4.30 daily.

item.title: Tiki Comedy - Free Weekly Comedy!
item.description:
Venture into Richmond's deliciously naughty Tiki Lounge & Bar to get boozed on pirate rum, stroke the furry (leopard) wall and laugh your tatas off!
Every week features an amazing line-up of 10 or so hilarious comics who will have you in stitches from beginning to end!
Gold coin donations welcome - for the month of July, all proceeds will go to The Lost Dogs' Home.
Bar is cash only.

item.title: Treasures and Tastes @ Trinity
item.description:
Held on the third Saturday of every month, the Treasures and Tastes @ Trinity is a local makers and producers market in Surrey Hills, Melbourne.
Stall holders make everything they sell themselves and the market has a range of stalls from fresh produce such as honey, vegetables, jams, cakes to wine, home crafts, children's clothes and accessories, art work.
Come and have a scone and hot drink in the Treasures Cafe or treat yourself to a yummy egg and bacon roll from the courtyard barbecue.
The market has a hidden treasures room with new stall every month. If your looking for a morning out and about, the Treasures and Tastes Market is the place to be.
The market is predominantly a, indoor market and cater for all weather!

item.title: Women of Feelings
item.description:
Women of Feelings features portraits of women created throughout the last year which have been painted in colours which reflect their personalities.
The collection portrays various women and their diverse life experiences. Or perhaps they are actually self portraits that reflect the varying emotions that are tied in with questioning one's identity as a woman and a migrant?

item.title: Wild Awards 2014 Exhibition of Wildlife Artworks
item.description:
The Wild Awards presents selected artworks by members of the Wildlife Art Society of Australasia. This exciting exhibition held only every second year, and this year marks the 40th anniversary of WASA. Everyone is welcome to the event celebration and exhibition, which features 2D and 3D artworks, including some spectacular bronzes.
Closes 2:30pm 30th Sept.

item.title: NGV Floor Talk Series – Italian Masterpieces
item.description:
See the NGV's extensive collection in a new light as staff take visitors through the permanent displays, making connections with artists and works featured in the Italian Masterpieces exhibition.
Fri 1 Aug Renaissance portraiture & personalities: Lucrezia Borgia Speaker Carl Villis, Conservator of European Paintings before 1800
Fri 8 Aug Love & marriage in the Italian Renaissance Speaker Dr Matthew Martin, Curator, Decorative Arts & Antiquities, and Sophie Matthiesson, Curator, International Art
Fri 15 Aug Veronese & Tiepolo Speaker Julia Jackson, Cataloguer
Fri 22 Aug Mengs and eighteenth century portraiture Speaker Laurie Benson, Curator, International Art
Fri 29 Aug Paola Pivi Speaker Max Delany, Senior Curator, Contemporary Art

item.title: Artists Emerge at WTC
item.description:
The Artists Emerge at WTC exhibition follows on from the success of the 2013 collaboration between WTC and MARS Gallery, 25 Sculptures at the WTC, and will showcase works from some of Victoria's most promising emerging sculptors.
The six-week exhibition, curated by Andy Dinan of MARS Gallery, will feature works created or finished in the last 12 months.
Running alongside the exhibition, a 'People's Choice Award' will be conducted through WTC social media.
Featured artists include: Daniel Agdag, Dr. Lisa Anderson, Merric Brettle, Piers Buxton, Nicole Byrne, ACAB Collective, Julie Collins & Derek John, Steve Cook, Melissa Cussell, Emma Davies, Sarah Field, Lloyd Godman, Matthew Harding, Kasia Lynch, Harley Manifold, Ana Cristina Jorge-Moore, Mike Nicholls, Jackie Ralph, GT Sewell, Maria Simonelli, Shoso Shimbo, Greer Taylor, Frank Veldze & Suzanne Donisthorpe, Marc Vellekoop, Tricky Walsh, Jud Wimhurst, Tim J S Wise, Bethany Wheeler and Christabel Wigley.

item.title: Wandin Park Horse Trials
item.description:
The Wandin Park Horse Trials is on again in 2015! This year Wandin Park will be holding the Australian National Championships and this will bring all the top eventers from all over Australia.
With lots of shopping and entertainment over the whole weekend. Bring a picnic or eat at the many catering options available.
A great weekend out for the whole family and it is free!
Wandin Park is only an hour east of the Melbourne City in the heart of the Yarra Valley.

item.title: Fiona Connor: Wallworks
item.description:
Presented across the entire museum, Wallworks is the first major solo exhibition in Australia by Los Angeles-based, New Zealand-born artist Fiona Connor.
The exhibition sees Connor work with the Monash University Collection and associated works to recreate the location and installation of a number of artworks that hang in offices, lecture theatres and public spaces across Monash campuses, bringing the various architectures of the University into the museum along with the artworks themselves.

item.title: Drawing on Drysdale
item.description:
Drawing on Drysdale presents drawings by an icon of 20th century Australian art, Russell Drysdale (1912-1981). This touring exhibition is built around the substantial holdings of Drysdale's work in the Albury City Collection.
This unique collection includes drawings, sketches, written material and objects, such as Drysdale's portable easel, in an exhibition that celebrates a major Australian artist responsible for reshaping the way we see Australia.
It was drawing that first brought attention to Russell Drysdale in the early 1930's, and also towards the end of his life when he was restricted due to ill health; it was drawing that once again occupied him. Through drawing Drysdale engaged with representation, touch and vision. He sought to create images that went beyond the depiction of appearances, wrestling with the significance of marks and mark making.
His unique style was informed by European modernism but boldly inspired by the people and places of Australia. He did not labour over details; rather he focussed on the essential features leaving the remaining image to the viewer's imagination.
Drawing on Drysdale brings together 40 drawings and ephemera into an exhibition that acknowledges one of the great Australian artists of the 20th Century.

item.title: Vietnam Veterans' Day
item.description:
Also known as Long Tan Day, Vietnam Veterans' Day falls on 18 August each year. This year marks the 52nd anniversary of Australia's entrance in to the Vietnam War. This service will be held on the Forecourt at the Shrine of Remembrance, Birdwood Avenue, Melbourne 3001.
See website for more information.

item.title: Meet the Rats
item.description: Meet the Rats of Tobruk, Ron Williamson and Bob Semple, as they share their recollections of the siege 73 years ago. Hear about their battle experiences, living conditions and the camaraderie which was shared by the Rats, as they were to be forevermore named. This mateship continues today in the Rats of Tobruk Association, supported by a broad network of friends honouring their efforts and contribution.

item.title: Friends Only: Opening of the Galleries of Remembrance
item.description:
This October, Friends of the Shrine are exclusively invited to preview the new Galleries of Remembrance before it opens to the public. Be among some of the first visitors to see remarkable exhibits, including the SS Devanha landing boat and Rolls of Honour displaying the names of all Victorians who enlisted in the Second World War, Korean War and Vietnam War. Full details, including the date of the event, will be announced on the Shrine website.
Support the Shrine and become a Friend. For further information contact David Howell, Fundraising and Friends Coordinator or visit the website.

image.altText: Friends Only: Opening of the Galleries of Remembrance
Friends Only: Opening of the Galleries of Remembrance

item.title: Forty Thousand Horsemen
item.description: In a cinematic tribute to the mounted troops of the Australian Light Horse regiments, director Charles Chauvel presents his 1940 feature-length film Forty Thousand Horsemen. Featuring iconic Australian actors Grant Taylor, Chips Rafferty and Pat Twohill, the story follows three best mates through challenging times as soldiers - from mischief in Cairo in 1916 through to the action of the Australian Light Horse in the charge of Beersheba. Join them for their first film screening in the Shrine's new auditorium.

item.title: Childrens Week Picnic
item.description:
Wyndham City will proudly present the Children's Week Picnic at Werribee Park on Sunday 26 October 2014 from 10am to 4pm.
This free event is a fun, family friendly day full of interactive activities for children. Sports, craft, music, dance and much more, ensure the little ones are engaged in healthy and active fun and play.
The Looney Tunes Show will entertain from the stage as well as children can meet their favourite character including Tweety, Daffy & Bugs Bunny!
Entry to the Picnic and all activities are free.

item.title: Bairnsdale Regional Lecture: The Other ANZACs
item.description:
Held at the Bairnsdale RSL, Peter Rees tells the story of the 'other' ANZACs who worked in the hospital camps, wards and tent surgeries on the edge of some of the most horrific battlefronts of human history.
Discussing their efforts and experiences from the outbreak of war, Peter provides insight to the dedication and strength of these Australian women. These were the women who left for war on an adventure and were soon confronted with remarkable challenges that their civilian lives could never have prepared them for.

item.title: ANZACS on the Wall
item.description: Singers, songwriters and entertainers, Jim Brown and Vince Brophy perform on the Lone Pine Guitar, crafted from a branch of the Shrine's former Lone Pine tree, to tell the story of Danny Clancy who, like so many young Australians, set off to fight in the First World War. Following the performance, the Lone Pine Guitar will be officially presented to the Shrine of Remembrance by its craftsman at Maton Guitars.

item.title: Surfacing Australia's Submarine Heritage
item.description:
One hundred years ago at the outbreak of the First World War, Australia had the most technologically potent submarine capability in the southern hemisphere: the E-class submarines.
Tragically in September 1914 AE1 went down with all hands. AE2 rallied and led the charge to be the first submarine in history to penetrate the Dardanelles military defences in Turkey on 25 April 1915.
Join maritime archaeologist and Executive Director of Heritage Victoria, Tim Smith, as he presents an illustrated talk on the fate of these submarines and their legacy.

item.title: Lost Boys of ANZAC
item.description:
In his most recent publication Lost Boys of ANZAC, Professor Stanley traces the first wave of Australian troops that landed on Gallipoli and died on 25 April 1915.
In finding out who these men were, how they died and how their families learned of and reacted to their deaths, Professor Stanley tells us things we never knew about the landing on Gallipoli. He offers sobering insights and salutary conclusions on the eve of the centenary of the Gallipoli campaign.

item.title: D-Day
item.description:
To commemorate the 70th anniversary of the D-Day Landings on 6 June 1944, Dr Mark Johnston discusses the largest seaborne invasion in history. Involving more than 150,000 Allied troops, including 3,000 Australians, the invasion of Normandy began the liberation of German-occupied Western Europe and contributed significantly to Allied victory in Second World War.
General Rommel, commanding German forces in France, prophesied that the day of the invasion would be 'the longest day', and as this talk will reveal, it was indeed a day of great stress, conflict and achievement.

item.title: For King and Country: Panel Discussion
item.description:
Two of Australia's renowned military historians will be joined by the Ambassador to Belgium to discuss the outbreak of the First World War which, in its time, was considered to be the war to end all wars. Not only focusing on the Australian perspective and contribution, this talk will provide an international perspective to the War which so many felt the cost of.
Presenters: Professor Bruce Scates, Dr Michael McKernan and His Excellency, Jean-Luc Bodson.

item.title: Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist – Paul Dempsey
item.description:
Throughout winter, NGV is hosting a series of music and conversations set amongst the classics of the 19th- and 20th-century Australian art galleries. See some of the most iconic works by Australian artists - from Rupert Bunny to John Brack - in a different light, explore shared themes between art and music, and enjoy a short set of live and intimate performances in the gallery spaces.
Curated by Jae Laffer of the Panics, Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist showcases 10 of the country's best emerging and established musicians and bands over 10 weeks. On Sunday afternoons, Laffer and NGV curators will discuss themes and ideas in iconic Australian works, followed by a live and acoustic performance of a handful of songs by the musicians.
Performing this week is Paul Dempsey, one of Australia's leading songwriters. On his debut solo album, 'Everything is True', the immense guitars and conclusive backbeat that Dempsey has orchestrated over Something For Kate's five acclaimed albums are put aside, succeeded by a striking new palette where a tender voice and expressive acoustic guitar are supplemented by airy rhythms, the expert punctuation of an electric guitar and gently immersive keyboards. This is music where light filters through the gaps, uplifting and eminently melodic.

item.title: Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist – Missy Higgins
item.description:
Throughout winter, NGV is hosting a series of music and conversations set amongst the classics of the 19th- and 20th-century Australian art galleries. See some of the most iconic works by Australian artists - from Rupert Bunny to John Brack - in a different light, explore shared themes between art and music, and enjoy a short set of live and intimate performances in the gallery spaces.
Curated by Jae Laffer of the Panics, Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist showcases 10 of the country's best emerging and established musicians and bands over 10 weeks. On Sunday afternoons, Laffer and NGV curators will discuss themes and ideas in iconic Australian works, followed by a live and acoustic performance of a handful of songs by the musicians.
In the last perfomance of the series, singer/songerwriter Missy Higgins will take to the microphone. She has struck a profound chord with Australian music fans with her irresistible melodies, 'arrow through the heart' lyrics and a voice that clearly means it.
After taking a break from music, Missy returned to the studio in 2011 to record her third #1 album, 'The Ol' Razzle Dazzle', which became the most acclaimed work of Missy's extraordinary career. The breakup album with a difference, chronicling the much-loved singer's estrangement - and eventual rapprochement - with music making, spent over three months in the top 10 after its mid-2012 release and became Missy's first release to make the Billboard Top 100 in America. Missy is currently working on a new album due for release later this year.

item.title: Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist – Jae Laffer
item.description:
Throughout winter, NGV is hosting a series of music and conversations set amongst the classics of the 19th- and 20th-century Australian art galleries. See some of the most iconic works by Australian artists - from Rupert Bunny to John Brack - in a different light, explore shared themes between art and music, and enjoy a short set of live and intimate performances in the gallery spaces.
Curated by Jae Laffer of the Panics, Unplugged Live: Portrait of an Artist showcases 10 of the country's best emerging and established musicians and bands over 10 weeks. On Sunday afternoons, Laffer and NGV curators will discuss themes and ideas in iconic Australian works, followed by a live and acoustic performance of a handful of songs by the musicians.
This week it's Jae's turn to perform. The ARIA and J Award-winning songwriter and frontman for the Panics released 'When the Iron Glows Red', his first solo album, in 2013. Laffer and the Panics have toured extensively across Australia and the world, and are currently working on their sixth studio album.

item.title: Ulm School of Design Exhibition
item.description:
This exhibition in the RMIT Gallery focuses on the educational concept of the so-called 'ulm model', revealing how it still affects today's design world.
The model's great variety and intellectual approaches are demonstrated by using large-format photos, text panels, an illustrated synopsis, models, graphic works, draft designs, products and videos. The school's influence on students all over the world will be illustrated through examples of design study programs in Latin America and Asia.
The exhibition is part of the 50th anniversary celebrations of the founding of the school and is presented by the Goethe-Institut in cooperation with the Institute for Foreign Cultural Relations. An adapted version of the exhibition has been touring the world since 2007.

item.title: Old Treasury Building Free Floor Talks
item.description:
Come along to the Old Treasury Free Floor Talk Series at 11am on the first Tuesday of every month.
Talks include:
- 1 July: Sandridge: the pier and the first rail link. - 5 August: Willamstown - 2 September: Troop ships - 7 October: Migrant ships - 18 November: Luxury liners.

item.title: Delicious
item.description:
In a shift back to the urban environment, William Breen's attention to detail is meticulous, with every cranny and layer illuminated in a pale, comic light. It is clear that the artist has a penchant (not to mention, skill) for conjuring these spaces in every nuance with his subject matter including graffiti, signage, aged facades, bicycles, grime and remnants of human activity. However, these inner-north neighbourhoods (think Fitzroy, Brunswick and Thornbury) contain not a single human soul.
This emptiness, where no one can be found, is especially unsettling in Breen's urban works. It might be natural for a blustering wilderness to be void of human trace, yet in the city, human activity etches itself on every available flank of concrete. In turn, the quiet of these paintings is uncanny. People are replaced with their trace. What remains is a stilled landscape of habitual living, where the figure in the scene becomes the viewer.

item.title: Air Force Band – Firebird
item.description:
Air Force Band presents 'Firebird', the third and final concert dedicated to celebrating the centenary of military aviation in Australia.
On 1 March 1914, one hundred years ago, the first military flight in Australia took place at Point Cook, the oldest continually operating military airfield in the world. Opening with Ron Goodwin's '633 Squadron', the Air Force Band will continue to celebrate the centenary of this momentous event and the significant advances in air and space power over the past 100 years. Stravinsky's spectacular 'Firebird Suite' will conclude this year's Iwaki concert series, showcasing the precision, agility and excellence of the Air Force Band.

item.title: Paper Arts Exhibition @ Mont De Lancey
item.description:
The Paper Arts exhibition is the collection of art forms employing paper as the primary artistic medium. It lends itself to a wide range of techniques, as it can for instance be printed on, folded, cut, glued, moulded, stitched, or layered. Papermaking by hand is also an important paper craft.
The exhibition opening is at 2pm on Saturday 1st November 2014 and runs until Sunday 23rd November 2014. Opening hours are 10:00am to 4:30pm.

image.altText: Paper Arts Exhibition @ Mont De Lancey
Paper Arts Exhibition @ Mont De Lancey

item.title: RMIT Lightscape Projects at Melbourne Central
item.description:
Working with RMIT's School of Art, Melbourne Central is transforming its well-known Knox Lane into an outdoor urban art gallery showcasing five lightbox artworks.
Melbourne Central is renowned for community projects which aim to enhance the traditional consumer retail experience and on June 17, Melbourne Central launched the Lightscape Projects, which will run until the end of August.
Lightscape Projects will transform Melbourne Central's Knox Lane into an outdoor urban art gallery displaying five artworks that are part of the public art project supported by RMIT which utilises permanent lightboxes as exhibition sites to display the work of emerging artists from the RMIT School Of Art.
The Lightscapes Projects challenges and redefines the placement of artwork in a gallery, activating public space through light. The lightboxes both contribute and connect with cultural dialogue of Melbourne and draw inspiration from the city itself adding to the dynamic laneway culture.
The artists represented investigate ideas of movement, moment and the rhythm of contemporary life. The work showcases the practices of Melbourne and Hong Kong based artists from the Bachelor of Art, Master of Fine Art, and PhD programs.

image.altText: RMIT Lightscape Projects at Melbourne Central
RMIT Lightscape Projects at Melbourne Central

item.title: Reflections: Australian landscape and still life
item.description:
Bundoora Homestead Art Centre is delighted to present Reflections: Australian Landscape & Still Life curated from the Castlemaine Art Gallery and Historical Museum Collection. This stunning exhibition journeys from the Golden Period of Australian Impressionism through the Edwardian era to modern and contemporary masters.
A love of still life by Australian artists, and in particular floral arrangements, is a feature of the exhibition, which includes work by A.M.E. Bale, Clarice Beckett, Rupert Bunny, Arthur Streeton and Margaret Preston. Preston's Flannel Flowers (c.1928), is a strong example of the fine line work and two-dimensional interpretation of still life via printmaking. Proteas, daisies and native flowers were carved into a woodblock and remind us of the vibrancy and colour of the bush.
Landscape is a recurring motif in the mediums of painting and watercolour. From the soft purple and blue brushstrokes of Frederick McCubbin's towering gums, to the isolated Surrealist cityscape by Rick Amor, the many facets of urban, rural and seascapes are represented in the exhibition.
Reflections: Australian Landscape & Still Life also features well known works by Geoffrey R. Anderson, Norma Bailey-Ramsey, John Borrack, Penleigh Boyd, Louis Buvelot, Elizabeth Colquhoun, Sybil Craig, Philip Davey, John Farmer, Ethel Carrick Fox, William Frater, Ian Fairweather, Craig Gough, John Longstaff, Dora Meeson, Lloyd Rees, Elma Roach, Jeffrey Smart, Alan Sumner, Fred Williams and Walter Withers.

item.title: Robert Jacks: Order & Variation
item.description:
This exhibition will represent the first large-scale retrospective of Robert Jacks who is one of Australia's most significant and accomplished abstract artists. From his first sell-out solo exhibition at Gallery A in Melbourne in 1966, through to his ongoing exploration of abstraction in painting, sculpture, drawing and printmaking, his work has charted a distinctive and influential path through late twentieth and early twenty-first century Australian art.
Born in 1943 Jacks studied sculpture at Prahran Technical College from 1958-1960 and painting at RMIT in 1961-62. His first solo exhibition was held to great acclaim in 1966 and in 1968 his work was included in the landmark exhibition, The Field, at the National Gallery of Victoria. Beginning in 1968, Jacks spent ten years living and working in Canada and the United States. It was during this period, much of which was spent in New York, in which Jacks met such artistic luminaries as Sol LeWitt and Donald Judd, and that his unique visual language matured, incorporating influences from the major exponents of contemporary abstraction, minimalism and conceptual practice. It is also this experience which makes Jacks a unique figure within the history and development of twentieth century Australian art.

item.title: I Think I Can
item.description:
Choose a miniature puppet and play out your new life on a large-scale model railway. I Think I Can brings together model trains, intricate puppetry, live video and active audience participation to create this innovative public artwork.
Participants first take a playful "career test" on a custom-built iPad application. The test calculates their personality and provides them a choice of puppets in professions to which they are suited, which encourages people to imagine themselves into another reality. They receive an intricately detailed human figure and are invited to imagine their resident's story.
This story is documented and appears in the online newspaper created for the residency. As the puppet is animated, its movements are filmed and the footage is streamed live onto screens above the installation.
Participants are given a "passport," which enables them to return to the miniature town at any time over the period of the engagement and move their figure again in relation to what has happened around them. As more characters arrive, the virtual community continues to expand, creating a community of storytelling.

item.title: Tchaikovsky's Pathétique
item.description:
This free one-hour concert features Tchaikovsky's most personal work, his Pathétique Symphony, whose hostile reception plunged Tchaikovsky into despair. This is one of his most heart-wrenching, passionate and beloved works.
The concert will also feature the second-ever performance of "The Death of Pythagóras at Metaпontum", a new work by the 2014 Zelman Symphony Melbourne University Emerging Composer, Michael Bakrnčev.

item.title: Surfacing Australia's Submarine Heritage
item.description:
One hundred years ago at the outbreak of the First World War, Australia had the most technologically potent submarine capability in the southern hemisphere: the E-class submarines.
Tragically, in September 1914 AE1 went down with all hands. AE2 rallied and led the charge to be the first submarine in history to penetrate the Dardanelles military defences in Turkey on 25 April 1915.
Join maritime archaeologist and Executive Director of Heritage Victoria, Tim Smith, as he presents an illustrated talk on the fate of these submarines and their legacy.

item.title: Fine Food Australia
item.description:
Celebrating 30 years of what has become a must-attend event for the food industry, Fine Food Australia returns to Melbourne in 2014.
Connecting buyers and sellers within the retail, food service and hospitality sectors, this show has something for everyone in the food industry. Be some of the first in Australia to see, touch and taste the latest food products, trends and innovations for 2014 while connecting with over 1,000 exhibitors.
Be inspired by live demonstrations, masterclasses and competitions run by some of the best in Australia while learning new ideas that can help improve your business. Don't miss out on your chance to be part of the largest food trade show in Australia!
Registrations are now open! Simply visit the website and register online for free. Online registrations close 5pm AEST Friday 12 September 2014. There is a $30 at-show charge for those who do not register online.
This is a business event. Entry is restricted to professionals in the food and hospitality industry and contractors servicing these industries. Persons not in this category, including children under the age of 16, will not be admitted at any time. Proof of identity and industry involvement may be requested at the door.

item.title: D Day Commemoration
item.description:
To commemorate the 70th anniversary of the D-Day Landings on 6 June 1944, Dr Mark Johnston discusses the largest seaborne invasion in history.
Involving more than 150,000 Allied troops, including 3000 Australians, the invasion of Normandy began the liberation of German-occupied Western Europe and contributed significantly to the Allied victory in the Second World War.
General Rommel, commanding German forces in France, prophesied that the day of the invasion would be ‘the longest day’, and as this talk will reveal, it was indeed a day of great stress, conflict and achievement.

item.title: Chinese Anzacs Exhibition Tour
item.description:
In the lead-up to the centenary of the First World War, Melbourne’s Chinese Museum is staging the exhibition Chinese Anzacs: Chinese-Australians and World War One.
Join this special guided tour of the exhibition, which explores some of the stories of the Chinese-Australians who served on the frontline. Limited spaces available.

ns0:venue.name: Chinese Museum and Chinatown Visitor Centre

item.title: Australian Volunteers Information Session
item.description:
If you're interested in volunteering overseas, come along to an information session to learn about a great Australian aid initiative - the Australian Volunteers for International Development (AVID) program.
Each year hundreds of Australians take up the challenge to live and work in developing countries as part of the Australian Government's Australian Volunteers for International Development program. Austraining International is a core partner in the Australian Volunteers for International Development program, an Australian aid initiative.
These Australian Volunteers work in a range of sectors including education, environment, IT, finance, sport, marketing/communications, health, law, gender as well as many others. Information sessions are an excellent opportunity to learn more about the AVID program.
Panelists of returned volunteers and Austraining staff will share their experiences and stories, as well as offer advice about applying and what to expect if successful.
The program provides: - Paid volunteer work through living allowances - Training before, during and after your volunteer assignment - Vaccinations - Medical and emergency support whilst in-country - Comprehensive insurance (travel, medical, security) - In-country support whilst on assignment - Flights - Visa costs
Refreshments provided.

item.title: Australia Will Be There
item.description:
Through historical photographs and personal stories, this exhibition presents the chronology of the First World War (1914-19) with particular reference to the contribution of Victorians.
Find out about the hardships that Australians endured and the battles they fought alongside Allied nations, from the landings at Gallipoli to the battles in Palestine, Passchendaele and Fromelles. Away from the frontline, discover the experiences of Australians back home in Victoria, and their contribution to the war effort. Also learn about the growing social divisions which climaxed in the bitterly contested and ultimately unsuccessful conscription referenda in 1916 and 1917.

item.title: Valkstone Primary School Fair
item.description:
Enjoy a great day out with family and friends at the Valkstone Primary School Fair.
Come and have a great day of fun at the Fair, with cakes, auction, lollies, games, rides, show bags, crafts, plants, raffles, novelties, toys, fairy floss, photo booth and much more.
Valkstone's Fair is held on Sunday, 9 November 2014, from 10 am to 3 pm.

item.title: Shirt and Skirt Markets
item.description:
Held in the grounds of the beautiful Abbotsford Convent, the Shirt and Skirt Markets are open on the third Sunday of each month throughout the year.
The Shirt and Skirt Markets is the perfect place for emerging fashion designers to showcase their talents and sell their beautiful creations to the general public. Mens, women's and children's fashion, as well as jewellery, homewares and skincare are just some of the things you'll find.
On the third Sunday of each month you will find four eateries, two markets, two art galleries, the Collingwood Children's Farm next door plus spacious heritage gardens, it's easy to spend a whole day at the Convent.

item.title: Mid Winter Wool & Wood
item.description:
